INFN, Sezione di Bologna, via Ranzani 1, 40127, Bologna, Italy), BO(Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, , 4800 Oak Grove Dr, Pasadena, CA, 91109, USA), BP(Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, , 4800 Oak Grove Dr, Pasadena, CA, 91109, USA), BQ(Dipartimento di Fisica, Univ. degli Studi di Trieste, via Tiepolo 11, 34143, Trieste, Italy; INAF-Osservatorio Astronomico di Trieste, via G. B. Tiepolo 11, 34131, Trieste, Italy), BR(European Laboratory for Particle Physics (CERN), 1211, Geneva 23, Switzerland), BS(Dipartimento di Fisica, Univ. degli Studi di Trieste, via Tiepolo 11, 34143, Trieste, Italy), BT(University Observatory Munich, Scheinerstrasse 1, 81679, M\u00fcnchen, Germany; Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr extraterrestrische Physik, Postfach 1312, Giessenbachstr., 85741, Garching, Germany), BU(Department of Physics and Astronomy, The Johns Hopkins University, 3400 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD, 21218, USA)"], "journal_name": "Astronomy and Astrophysics", "volume": "558", "publication_year": "2013/10/1", "start_page": "A1", "keywords": ["galaxies: clusters: individual: MACS J1206-0847", "galaxies: kinematics and dynamics", "galaxies: evolution", "dark matter", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2013A&A...558A...1B", "abstract": "<BR /> Aims: We constrain the mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of the z = 0.44 CLASH cluster <ASTROBJ>MACS J1206.2-0847</ASTROBJ>, using the projected phase-space distribution of cluster galaxies in combination with gravitational lensing. <BR /> Methods: We use an unprecedented data-set of \u2243600 redshifts for cluster members, obtained as part of a VLT/VIMOS large program, to constrain the cluster mass profile over the radial range ~0-5 Mpc (0-2.5 virial radii) using the MAMPOSSt and Caustic methods. We then add external constraints from our previous gravitational lensing analysis. We invert the Jeans equation to obtain the velocity-anisotropy profiles of cluster members. With the mass-density and velocity-anisotropy profiles we then obtain the first determination of a cluster pseudo-phase-space density profile. <BR /> Results: The kinematics and lensing determinations of the cluster mass profile are in excellent agreement. This is very well fitted by a NFW model with mass M<SUB>200</SUB> = (1.4 \u00b1 0.2) \u00d7 10<SUP>15</SUP> M<SUB>\u2299</SUB> and concentration c<SUB>200</SUB> = 6 \u00b1 1, only slightly higher than theoretical expectations. Other mass profile models also provide acceptable fits to our data, of (slightly) lower (Burkert, Hernquist, and Softened Isothermal Sphere) or comparable (Einasto) quality than NFW. The velocity anisotropy profiles of the passive and star-forming cluster members are similar, close to isotropic near the center and increasingly radial outside. Passive cluster members follow extremely well the theoretical expectations for the pseudo-phase-space density profile and the relation between the slope of the mass-density profile and the velocity anisotropy. Star-forming cluster members show marginal deviations from theoretical expectations. <BR /> Conclusions: This is the most accurate determination of a cluster mass profile out to a radius of 5 Mpc, and the only determination of the velocity-anisotropy and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of both passive and star-forming galaxies for an individual cluster. These profiles provide constraints on the dynamical history of the cluster and its galaxies. Prospects for extending this analysis to a larger cluster sample are discussed. <P />Based in large part on data collected at the ESO VLT (prog. ID 186.A-0798), at the NASA HST, and at the NASJ Subaru telescope.Appendices are available in electronic form at <A href=\"http://www.aanda.org\">http://www.aanda.org</A>", "doi": "10.1051/0004-6361/201321955", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1307.5867", "issn": "0004-6361"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2013A&A...558A...1B", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2013/10/aa21955-13.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: individual: MACS J1206-0847\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: kinematics and dynamics\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: evolution\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"dark matter\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims. &lt;i/&gt;We constrain the mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of the &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a00.44 CLASH cluster MACS J1206.2-0847, using the projected phase-space distribution of cluster galaxies in combination with gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Methods. &lt;i/&gt;We use an unprecedented data-set of \u2243600 redshifts for cluster members, obtained as part of a VLT/VIMOS large program, to constrain the cluster mass profile over the radial range ~0\u20135 Mpc (0\u20132.5 virial radii) using the MAMPOSSt and Caustic methods. We then add external constraints from our previous gravitational lensing analysis. We invert the Jeans equation to obtain the velocity-anisotropy profiles of cluster members. With the mass-density and velocity-anisotropy profiles we then obtain the first determination of a cluster pseudo-phase-space density profile.&lt;i&gt;Results. &lt;i/&gt;The kinematics and lensing determinations of the cluster mass profile are in excellent agreement. This is very well fitted by a NFW model with mass &lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a0(1.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010&lt;sup&gt;15&lt;sup/&gt;\u00a0&lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt; and concentration &lt;i&gt;c&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01, only slightly higher than theoretical expectations. Other mass profile models also provide acceptable fits to our data, of (slightly) lower (Burkert, Hernquist, and Softened Isothermal Sphere) or comparable (Einasto) quality than NFW. The velocity anisotropy profiles of the passive and star-forming cluster members are similar, close to isotropic near the center and increasingly radial outside. Passive cluster members follow extremely well the theoretical expectations for the pseudo-phase-space density profile and the relation between the slope of the mass-density profile and the velocity anisotropy. Star-forming cluster members show marginal deviations from theoretical expectations.&lt;i&gt;Conclusions. &lt;i/&gt;This is the most accurate determination of a cluster mass profile out to a radius of 5 Mpc, and the only determination of the velocity-anisotropy and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of both passive and star-forming galaxies for an individual cluster. These profiles provide constraints on the dynamical history of the cluster and its galaxies. Prospects for extending this analysis to a larger cluster sample are discussed.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=M. H. Abdullah;citation_author=G. B. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div C/Camino Bajo de Hu&#233;tor\n              24,  18008 \n             Granada,\n             Spain \n        <br>\n          <sup>22</sup> \n          Department of Theoretical Physics, University of the Basque\n              Country,  PO Box\n            644,  48080 \n             Bilbao,\n             Spain \n        <br>\n          <sup>23</sup> \n          Department of Astronomy, Universidad de Concepcion,\n               Casilla 160-C,  Concepcion,  Chile \n        <br>\n          <sup>24</sup> \n          Department of Physics and Astronomy, Michigan State\n              University,  East\n              Lansing,  MI \n             48824,\n             USA \n        <br>\n          <sup>25</sup> \n          Laboratoire AIM-Paris-Saclay, CEA/DSM-CNRS, Universit&#233; Paris\n              Diderot, Irfu/Service d&#8217;Astrophysique, CEA Saclay,  Orme des Merisiers,  91191 \n             Gif-sur-Yvette,\n               France \n        <br>\n          <sup>26</sup> \n          Department of Astronomy, University of California,\n               Berkeley,  CA,  USA \n        <br>\n          <sup>27</sup> \n          Department of Astrophysical Sciences, Princeton\n              University,  Princeton,  NJ,\n               USA \n        <br>\n          <sup>28</sup> \n          Department of Physics, The Ohio State University,\n               Columbus,  OH,  USA \n        <br>\n          <sup>29</sup> \n          Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology,\n               4800 Oak Grove Dr,\n               Pasadena,  CA \n             91109,\n             USA \n        <br>\n          <sup>30</sup> \n           European Laboratory for Particle Physics (CERN),\n               1211 \n             Geneva 23,\n               Switzerland \n        <br>\n          <sup>31</sup> \n           University Observatory Munich,  Scheinerstrasse 1,  81679 \n             M&#252;nchen,\n             Germany \n        <br>\n          <sup>32</sup> \n           Max-Planck-Institut f&#252;r extraterrestrische Physik,\n              Postfach 1312,\n              Giessenbachstr.,  85741 \n             Garching,\n             Germany \n        <br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>\n          24 \n          May \n          2013\n        <br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>\n          29 \n          July \n          2013\n        </p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n        <p><i>Aims. </i>We constrain the mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space\n          density profiles of the <i>z</i>&#160;=&#160;0.44 CLASH cluster <a href=\"http://cdsweb.u-strasbg.fr/cgi-bin/bibobj?2013A%26A...558A...1B&amp;MACS+J1206.2-0847\" target=\"_blank\">MACS J1206.2-0847</a>, using the projected phase-space\n          distribution of cluster galaxies in combination with gravitational lensing.</p>\n        <p><i>Methods. </i>We use an unprecedented data-set of &#8771;600 redshifts for cluster\n          members, obtained as part of a VLT/VIMOS large program, to constrain the cluster mass\n          profile over the radial range ~0&#8211;5 Mpc (0&#8211;2.5 virial radii) using the MAMPOSSt and Caustic\n          methods. We then add external constraints from our previous gravitational lensing\n          analysis. We invert the Jeans equation to obtain the velocity-anisotropy profiles of\n          cluster members. With the mass-density and velocity-anisotropy profiles we then obtain the\n          first determination of a cluster pseudo-phase-space density profile.</p>\n        <p><i>Results. </i>The kinematics and lensing determinations of the cluster mass\n          profile are in excellent agreement. This is very well fitted by a NFW model with mass\n            <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;(1.4&#160;&#177;&#160;0.2)&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>15</sup>&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>\n          and concentration <i>c</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;6&#160;&#177;&#160;1, only slightly higher than\n          theoretical expectations. Other mass profile models also provide acceptable fits to our\n          data, of (slightly) lower (Burkert, Hernquist, and Softened Isothermal Sphere) or\n          comparable (Einasto) quality than NFW. The velocity anisotropy profiles of the passive and\n          star-forming cluster members are similar, close to isotropic near the center and\n          increasingly radial outside. Passive cluster members follow extremely well the theoretical\n          expectations for the pseudo-phase-space density profile and the relation between the slope\n          of the mass-density profile and the velocity anisotropy. Star-forming cluster members show\n          marginal deviations from theoretical expectations.</p>\n        <p><i>Conclusions. </i>This is the most accurate determination of a cluster mass\n          profile out to a radius of 5 Mpc, and the only determination of the velocity-anisotropy\n          and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of both passive and star-forming galaxies for an\n          individual cluster. These profiles provide constraints on the dynamical history of the\n          cluster and its galaxies. Prospects for extending this analysis to a larger cluster sample\n          are discussed.</p>\n      <div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>galaxies: clusters: individual: MACS J1206-0847 / galaxies: kinematics and dynamics / galaxies: evolution / dark matter</p></div>\n<div class=\"note\">\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN1\"></a><sup>&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Based in large part on data collected at the ESO VLT (prog. ID 186.A-0798), at the\n              NASA HST, and at the NASJ Subaru telescope.</p>\n</div>\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN2\"></a><sup>&#8902;&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Appendices are available in electronic form at <a href=\"http://www.aanda.org\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.aanda.org</a></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; ESO, 2013</i></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>Clusters of galaxies are excellent cosmological natural laboratories. They are the most\n        massive systems in dynamical equilibrium, and are thus extremely sensitive and effective\n        cosmological probes, especially through the study of the cluster mass function (e.g. <a name=\"InR111\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R111\">Kravtsov &amp; Borgani 2012</a>, and references herein).\n        These systems are believed to be dominated by dark matter (DM hereafter, <a name=\"InR216\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R216\">Zwicky 1933</a>), so their internal mass distribution can in\n        principle be used to distinguish between DM and alternative theories of gravity (e.g. <a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R49\">Clowe et al. 2006</a>), or to constrain the intrinsic\n        physical properties of DM (e.g. <a name=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R6\">Arabadjis et al. 2002</a>;\n          <a name=\"InR136\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R136\">Markevitch et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR103\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R103\">Katgert et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR186\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R186\">Serra &amp;\n          Dom&#237;nguez Romero 2011</a>). </p>\n<p>According to cold DM cosmological numerical simulations, the radial mass distribution of DM\n        halos is universal, and their mass density profiles can be characterized by a simple\n        function of the radial distance (NFW model hereafter; <a name=\"InR153\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R153\">Navarro et al. 1996</a>, <a name=\"InR154\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R154\">1997</a>), at least out\n        to the virial radius<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#FN4\">1</a></sup>,\n        <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>. The NFW model parameters are the virial radius\n          <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>, and the scale radius <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>,\n        that is the radius where the logarithmic derivative of the mass density profile\n          <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8801;&#160;dln<i>&#961;</i>/dln<i>r</i>&#160;=&#160;&#8722;2.\n        Equivalently, the NFW model can be characterized by the related parameters, the virial\n          mass<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#FN5\">2</a></sup><i>M</i><sub>200</sub>, and the\n        concentration\n          <i>c</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;&#8801;&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>/<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>.\n        An even better fit to the density profile of cosmological halos can be obtained using the\n          <a name=\"InR65\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R65\">Einasto (1965)</a> model (<a name=\"InR155\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R155\">Navarro et al. 2004</a>). Observations have confirmed that the universal NFW\n        model provides adequate fit </p>\n<p>to the mass distribution of clusters (e.g. <a name=\"InR44\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R44\">Carlberg et al.\n          1997a</a>; <a name=\"InR80\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R80\">Geller et al. 1999</a>; <a name=\"InR205\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R205\">van der Marel et al. 2000</a>; <a name=\"InR108\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R108\">King et al. 2002</a>; <a name=\"InR29\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R29\">Biviano &amp;\n          Girardi 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR174\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R174\">Rines et al. 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR110\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R110\">Kneib et al. 2003</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R103\">Katgert et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR8\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R8\">Arnaud et al. 2005</a>;\n          <a name=\"InR40\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R40\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR202\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R202\">Umetsu et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR159\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R159\">Oguri et al.\n          2012</a>; <a name=\"InR161\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R161\">Okabe et al. 2013</a>). </p>\n<p>Many studies have attempted to explain the NFW-like shape of the mass density profile of\n        cosmological halos, and why this shape is universal, even if universality is still a debated\n        issue (e.g. <a name=\"InR169\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R169\">Ricotti 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR197\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R197\">Tasitsiomi et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR141\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R141\">Merritt et al.\n          2006</a>; <a name=\"InR170\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R170\">Ricotti et al. 2007</a>). While some\n        studies have found the shape of halo density profiles to depend on cosmology (e.g. <a name=\"InR193\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R193\">Subramanian et al. 2000</a>; <a name=\"InR200\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R200\">Thomas et al. 2001</a>; <a name=\"InR177\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R177\">Salvador-Sol&#233; et\n          al. 2007</a>), others have not (<a name=\"InR96\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R96\">Huss et al.\n          1999a</a>; <a name=\"InR208\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R208\">Wang &amp; White 2009</a>). A\n        general consensus is growing that the universal NFW-like shape, at least in the central\n        regions, is the result of the initial, fast assembly phase of halos (<a name=\"InR97\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R97\">Huss et al. 1999b</a>; <a name=\"InR135\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R135\">Manrique et al.\n          2003</a>; <a name=\"InR7\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R7\">Arad et al. 2004</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R197\">Tasitsiomi et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR125\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R125\">Lu et al.\n          2006</a>; <a name=\"InR67\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R67\">El-Zant 2008</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R208\">Wang &amp; White 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR114\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R114\">Lapi\n          &amp; Cavaliere 2011</a>), characterized by dynamical processes such as violent and\n        collective relaxation, and phase and chaotic mixing (<a name=\"InR91\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R91\">H&#233;non\n          1964</a>; <a name=\"InR127\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R127\">Lynden-Bell 1967</a>; <a name=\"InR140\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R140\">Merritt 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR92\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R92\">Henriksen\n          2006</a>, and references therein). The following slower accretion phase may be\n        responsible for the outer slope of the density profile (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R197\">Tasitsiomi et al. 2004</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R125\">Lu et al. 2006</a>;\n          <a name=\"InR94\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R94\">Hiotelis 2006</a>). Halos would obtain the same,\n        universal density profile independently of details about their collapse (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R67\">El-Zant 2008</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R208\">Wang\n          &amp; White 2009</a>) and subsequent merger histories (<a name=\"InR54\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R54\">Dehnen 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR104\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R104\">Kazantzidis et al.\n          2006</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R67\">El-Zant 2008</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R208\">Wang &amp; White 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR178\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R178\">Salvador-Sol&#233; et al. 2012</a>). </p>\n<p>It has been argued by <a name=\"InR198\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R198\">Taylor &amp; Navarro\n          (2001)</a> that the NFW-like shape is strictly related to the power-law radial behavior\n        of the pseudo-phase-space density profiles of halos identified in cosmological numerical\n        simulations,\n          <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>)&#160;&#8801;&#160;<i>&#961;</i>/<i>&#963;</i><sup>3</sup>&#160;&#8733;&#160;<i>r</i><sup>&#8722;<i>&#945;</i></sup>\n        with <i>&#945;</i>&#160;=&#160;&#8722;1.875. This power-law behavior of\n          <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) is obeyed by a variety of self-gravitating\n        collisionless systems in equilibrium, not necessarily formed as the result of hierarchical\n        accretion processes, and this suggests that it is a generic result of the collisionless\n        collapse, probably induced by violent relaxation (<a name=\"InR9\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R9\">Austin et\n          al. 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R14\">Barnes et al. 2006</a>). A similar\n        power-law behavior is also obtained for\n          <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>), where the total\n        velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i> is replaced with its radial component,\n          <i>&#963;</i><sub><i>r</i></sub> (<a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R55\">Dehnen\n          &amp; McLaughlin 2005</a>). </p>\n<p>The power-law behavior may however not hold at all radii (<a name=\"InR182\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R182\">Schmidt et al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR126\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R126\">Ludlow et al. 2010</a>)\n        and depending on the virialization state of the system, departure from power-law may start\n        already close to the center, or, for more virialized halos, near the virial radius (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R126\">Ludlow et al. 2010</a>). In any case, the relation is\n        surprisingly similar to the self-similar solution of <a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R22\">Bertschinger (1985)</a> for secondary infall onto a spherical perturbation, even if\n        the reason for this similarity remains unexplained. </p>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R55\">Dehnen &amp; McLaughlin (2005)</a> have shown that\n        the shape of the density profiles of cosmological halos follows analytically from the\n        power-law behavior of <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) if the system obeys the Jeans\n        equation of dynamical equilibrium (<a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R25\">Binney &amp; Tremaine\n          1987</a>), and if a linear <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation holds,\n          with<a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq19.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span>where\n          <i>&#963;</i><sub><i>&#952;</i></sub>,<i>&#963;</i><sub><i>&#966;</i></sub>\n        are the two tangential components, and <i>&#963;</i><sub><i>r</i></sub> the\n        radial component, of the velocity dispersion, and the last equivalence is obtained in the\n        case of spherical symmetry. The existence of such a linear\n          <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation has been found by </p>\n<p><a name=\"InR87\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R87\">Hansen &amp; Moore (2006)</a> to hold in a variety\n        of halos extracted from numerical simulations, <a name=\"FD2\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq22.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(2)</span></span>The reality of this\n        relation has been questioned by <a name=\"InR156\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R156\">Navarro et al.\n          (2010)</a> and <a name=\"InR120\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R120\">Lemze et al. (2012)</a> and yet some\n        relation does seem to exist between the shape of a halo mass density profile and the orbital\n        properties of the halo constituents (see also <a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R5\">An &amp;\n          Evans 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR89\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R89\">Hansen et al. 2006</a>, <a name=\"InR90\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R90\">2010</a>; <a name=\"InR100\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R100\">Iguchi et al.\n          2006</a>; <a name=\"InR206\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R206\">Van Hese et al. 2011</a>). For a NFW-like\n        density profile, the <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation would imply isotropic\n        orbits (<i>&#946;</i>&#160;&#8776;&#160;0) near the center, and more radially anisotropic orbits\n          (<i>&#946;</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;0) outside, as observed in DM halos. The\n        radius where <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) departs from isotropy,\n          <i>r</i><sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>, is then naturally related to the\n        characteristic scale length <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> of the DM density profile (<a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R13\">Barnes et al. 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R19\">Bellovary et al. 2008</a>). A relation between <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> and\n          <i>r</i><sub><i>&#946;</i></sub> has indeed been found in numerically\n        simulated halos (<a name=\"InR15\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R15\">Barnes et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR133\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R133\">Mamon et al. 2010</a>). </p>\n<p>Like the power-law behavior of <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>), also the\n          <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation might be related to the halo formation\n        process. Isotropization of orbits may result from fluctuations in the gravitational\n        potential during the fast-accretion phase characterized by major mergers, i.e. a sort of\n        violent or chaotic relaxation (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R125\">Lu et al. 2006</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R114\">Lapi &amp; Cavaliere 2011</a>). The subsequent slow,\n        gentle phase of mass accretion is unable to isotropize orbits and as a consequence the\n        external, more recently accreted material would tend to move on more radially elongated\n        orbits. Another process capable of generating isotropic orbits near the center of halos from\n        an initial distribution of radial orbits is the radial orbit instability (ROI hereafter).\n        ROI occurs when particles in precessing elongated loop orbits experience a torque due to a\n        slight asymmetry, that causes them to lose some angular momentum and move toward the system\n        center (see, e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R19\">Bellovary et al. 2008</a>). ROI\n        continues even after the halo has virialized (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R15\">Barnes et al.\n          2007</a>). </p>\n<p>So far we have seen that the <i>shapes </i>of the mass density and velocity\n        anisotropy profiles seem to carry information on the formation processes of cosmological\n        halos but not on the cosmological model. The latter might however be constrained by the\n        relation between the two parameters of the mass density profile,\n          <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>, the so-called\n        concentration-mass relation (<i>cMr</i> hereafter). In fact, the halo\n        concentration is determined by the mass fraction accreted into the cluster during the\n        initial fast phase (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R125\">Lu et al. 2006</a>) so\n          <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>M</i><sub>200</sub> identify to a large\n        extent the formation redshift of a halo (see, e.g., <a name=\"InR78\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R78\">Gao et\n          al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR83\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R83\">Giocoli et al. 2012b</a>). Observing\n        the <i>cMr</i> at different redshifts can therefore be used to constrain\n        cosmological models (see, e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R96\">Huss et al. 1999a</a>;\n          <a name=\"InR60\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R60\">Dolag et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR213\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R213\">Wong &amp; Taylor 2012</a>). For example, it has been found that the\n          <i>cMr</i> has opposite slopes in Cold and Hot DM cosmologies (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R208\">Wang &amp; White 2009</a>), while in\n        dark-energy-dominated Warm DM models the <i>cMr</i> is not monotonous but\n        characterized by a turnover point at group mass scales (<a name=\"InR183\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R183\">Schneider et al. 2012</a>). </p>\n<p>At present there is some tension between the observed <i>cMr</i> (e.g. <a name=\"InR124\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R124\">&#321;okas et al. 2006b</a>; <a name=\"InR171\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R171\">Rines &amp; Diaferio 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR42\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R42\">Buote et al.\n          2007</a>; <a name=\"InR181\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R181\">Schmidt &amp; Allen 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR28\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R28\">Biviano 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R70\">Ettori et\n          al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR160\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R160\">Okabe et al. 2010</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R159\">Oguri et al. 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR158\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R158\">Newman et al. 2013</a>) and that obtained in &#923;CDM cosmological simulations (e.g. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R154\">Navarro et al. 1997</a>; <a name=\"InR41\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R41\">Bullock et al. 2001</a>; <a name=\"InR62\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R62\">Duffy et al. 2008</a>;\n          <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R78\">Gao et al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR109\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R109\">Klypin et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR148\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R148\">Mu&#241;oz-Cuartas et al.\n          2011</a>; <a name=\"InR82\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R82\">Giocoli et al. 2012a</a>; <a name=\"InR23\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R23\">Bhattacharya et al. 2013</a>), particularly at the low mass\n        end (galaxy groups). The use of the <i>cMr</i> for discriminating among different\n        cosmological models is however somewhat hampered by our ignorance of baryon-related physical\n        processes that can change halo concentrations, also as a function of halo </p>\n<p>mass (e.g. <a name=\"InR68\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R68\">El-Zant et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR84\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R84\">Gnedin et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR12\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R12\">Barkana &amp; Loeb 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR57\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R57\">Del Popolo\n          2010</a>; <a name=\"InR74\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R74\">Fedeli 2012</a>). <a name=\"InR168\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R168\">Rasia et al. (2013)</a> have shown that the effect of baryons is not enough\n        to reconcile the observed and simulated <i>cMr</i>. Efficient radiative cooling\n        and weak feedback are needed to reconcile the observed and simulated <i>cMr</i> on\n        the scale of galaxy groups, but this comes at the price of creating tension with other\n        observables, such as the stellar mass fraction (<a name=\"InR63\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R63\">Duffy et al.\n          2010</a>). </p>\n<p>The above theoretical considerations about the universality, the shape, and the origin of\n        cluster mass profiles need to be tested observationally. Determining cluster mass profiles\n        is however not a simple task. Traditionally, this has been done using cluster galaxies as\n        tracers of the gravitational potential (e.g. <a name=\"InR105\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R105\">Kent &amp;\n          Gunn 1982</a>; <a name=\"InR199\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R199\">The &amp; White 1986</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R205\">van der Marel et al. 2000</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R29\">Biviano &amp; Girardi 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R26\">Biviano\n          2000</a>, and references therein) &#8211; this technique has allowed the first discovery of\n        dark matter (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R216\">Zwicky 1933</a>). The intra-cluster gas has\n        been used as tracer of the gravitational potential since the advent of X-ray astronomy (e.g.\n          <a name=\"InR144\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R144\">Mitchell et al. 1977</a>; <a name=\"InR77\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R77\">Forman &amp; Jones 1982</a>; <a name=\"InR72\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R72\">Fabricant et\n          al. 1986</a>; <a name=\"InR39\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R39\">Briel et al. 1992</a>; <a name=\"InR69\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R69\">Ettori et al. 2002</a>). Cluster masses and mass profiles can\n        also be measured using the Sunyaev-Zeldovich (<a name=\"InR194\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R194\">Sunyaev\n          &amp; Zeldovich 1970</a>) effect (e.g. <a name=\"InR163\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R163\">Pointecouteau et al. 1999</a>; <a name=\"InR85\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R85\">Grego et al.\n          2000</a>; <a name=\"InR115\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R115\">LaRoque et al. 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR149\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R149\">Muchovej et al. 2007</a>), but perhaps the most direct way\n        is by exploiting the gravitational distortion effects of the cluster potential on the\n        apparent shapes of background galaxies (e.g. <a name=\"InR207\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R207\">Wambsganss et\n          al. 1989</a>; <a name=\"InR137\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R137\">Mellier et al. 1993</a>; <a name=\"InR192\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R192\">Squires et al. 1996</a>; <a name=\"InR179\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R179\">Sand et al. 2002</a>; <a name=\"InR51\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R51\">Dahle et al. 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR214\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R214\">Zitrin et al. 2011</a>) as first suggested by <a name=\"InR217\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R217\">Zwicky (1937)</a>. </p>\n<p>Using different methods to determine cluster mass profiles is fundamental since different\n        methods suffer from different systematics. For instance, X-ray determinations of cluster\n        masses tend to be underestimated if bulk gas motions and the complex thermal structure of\n        the Intra-Cluster Medium (ICM) are ignored (<a name=\"InR166\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R166\">Rasia et al.\n          2004</a>, <a name=\"InR167\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R167\">2006</a>; <a name=\"InR116\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R116\">Lau et al. 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR145\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R145\">Molnar et al.\n          2010</a>; <a name=\"InR46\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R46\">Cavaliere et al. 2011</a>). Cluster\n        triaxiality and orientation effects tend to bias the mass profile estimates obtained by\n        gravitational lensing (e.g. <a name=\"InR138\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R138\">Meneghetti et al. 2011</a>;\n          <a name=\"InR17\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R17\">Becker &amp; Kravtsov 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR75\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R75\">Feroz &amp; Hobson 2012</a>) and by cluster galaxy\n        kinematics (<a name=\"InR48\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R48\">Cen 1997</a>; <a name=\"InR37\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R37\">Biviano et al. 2006</a>). Comparing different mass profile determinations can\n        therefore help assessing the contribution of nonthermal pressure to the ICM and the\n        elongation along the line-of-sight (e.g. <a name=\"InR146\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R146\">Morandi &amp;\n          Limousin 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR185\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R185\">Sereno et al. 2012</a>). If\n        systematics are well under control, the comparison of independent determinations of cluster\n        mass profiles from gravitational lensing and the kinematics of cluster members can shed\n        light on the very nature of DM (<a name=\"InR71\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R71\">Faber &amp; Visser\n          2006</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R186\">Serra &amp; Dom&#237;nguez Romero\n        2011</a>). </p>\n<p>While different methods can be used to constrain a cluster mass profile, direct\n        determination of its velocity-anisotropy profile <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) can\n        only be achieved by using cluster galaxies as tracers of the gravitational potential (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R105\">Kent &amp; Gunn 1982</a>; <a name=\"InR106\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R106\">Kent &amp; Sargent 1983</a>; <a name=\"InR143\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R143\">Millington\n          &amp; Peach 1986</a>; <a name=\"InR188\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R188\">Sharples et al. 1988</a>;\n          <a name=\"InR152\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R152\">Natarajan &amp; Kneib 1996</a>; <a name=\"InR36\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R36\">Biviano et al. 1997</a>; <a name=\"InR45\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R45\">Carlberg et al. 1997b</a>; <a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R2\">Adami et al. 1998a</a>;\n          <a name=\"InR131\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R131\">Mahdavi et al. 1999</a>; <a name=\"InR122\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R122\">&#321;okas &amp; Mamon 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R30\">Biviano\n          &amp; Katgert 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR130\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R130\">Mahdavi &amp; Geller\n          2004</a>; <a name=\"InR20\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R20\">Benatov et al. 2006</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R124\">&#321;okas et al. 2006b</a>; <a name=\"InR98\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R98\">Hwang &amp; Lee 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R4\">Adami et al. 2009</a>;\n          <a name=\"InR31\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R31\">Biviano &amp; Poggianti 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR118\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R118\">Lemze et al. 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR211\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R211\">Wojtak &amp; &#321;okas 2010</a>). </p>\n<p>In this paper we present a new determination of the mass and velocity anisotropy profiles\n        of a massive, X-ray selected cluster at redshift <i>z</i>&#160;=&#160;0.44, largely based on\n        spectroscopic data collected at ESO VLT. These data have been collected within the ESO Large\n        Programme 186.A-0798 &#8220;Dark Matter Mass Distributions of Hubble Treasury Clusters and the\n        Foundations of &#923;CDM Structure Formation Models&#8221; (P.I. Piero Rosati). This is an ongoing\n        spectroscopic follow-up of a subset of 14 clusters from the &#8220;Cluster Lensing And Supernova\n        survey with Hubble&#8221; (CLASH, <a name=\"InR164\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R164\">Postman et al. 2012</a>).\n        The CLASH-VLT Large Programme is aimed at obtaining redshift measurements for 400&#8211;600\n        cluster members and 10&#8211;20 lensed multiple images in each cluster field. We combine our\n        cluster mass profile determination based on spectroscopic data for member galaxies, with\n        independent mass profile determinations obtained from the strong and weak gravitational\n        lensing analyses of, respectively, <a name=\"InR215\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R215\">Zitrin et al.\n          (2012)</a> and <a name=\"InR203\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">Umetsu et al. (2012, U12\n          hereafter)</a>. The combined power of the excellent imaging and spectroscopic data\n        allows us to determine the mass profile for a single cluster to an unprecedented accuracy\n        and free of systematics over the radial range ~0&#8211;5 Mpc (corresponding to 0&#8211;2.5 virial\n        radii). The cluster mass profile so obtained is then used to determine the velocity\n        anisotropy profiles, <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) of both the passive and\n        star-forming cluster galaxy populations, for the first time for an individual cluster,\n        thanks to the large sample of spectroscopic redshifts. This is the highest-redshift\n        determination of <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) for an individual cluster so far.\n        The mass profile and <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) determinations are then used to\n        determine (for the first time ever for a real galaxy cluster) the pseudo-phase-space density\n        profiles <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n            <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>), and the\n          <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation. </p>\n<p>The paper is organized as follows. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S2\">2</a> we\n        describe the data sample, and the identification of cluster members. We determine the\n        cluster mass profile in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S5\">3</a> and compare our results\n        to theoretical expectations for the <i>cMr</i>. We determine the cluster velocity\n        anisotropy profile in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S9\">4</a>. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S10\">5</a> we test observationally the theoretical\n          <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>),\n          <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>), and\n          <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation. We discuss our results in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S11\">6</a> and provide our conclusions in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S15\">7</a>. In Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S17\">A</a> we\n        show that our results are robust vs. different choices of the method for cluster members\n        identification. In Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S18\">B</a> we compare our results\n        for the cluster mass with previous, less accurate results from the literature. </p>\n<p>Throughout this paper, we adopt <i>H</i><sub>0</sub>&#160;=&#160;70 km s<sup>-1</sup>\n          Mpc<sup>-1</sup>, &#937;<sub>0</sub>&#160;=&#160;0.3, &#937;<sub>&#923;</sub>&#160;=&#160;0.7. At the cluster redshift, 1\n        arcmin corresponds to 0.34 Mpc. Magnitudes are in the AB system. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. The data sample</h2>\n<p>The cluster MACS J1206.2-0847 was observed in 2012 as part of the ESO Large Programme\n        186.A-0798 using VIMOS (<a name=\"InR117\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R117\">Le F&#232;vre et al. 2003</a>) at the\n        ESO VLT. The VIMOS data were acquired using four separate pointings, each with a different\n        quadrant centered on the cluster core. A total of 12 masks were observed (8 LR-Blue masks\n        and 4 MR masks), and each mask was observed for either 3 or 4&#160;&#215;&#160;15 min, for a total of 10.7\n        h exposure time. The LR-Blue masks cover the spectral range 370&#8722;670 nm with a resolution\n          <i>R</i>&#160;=&#160;180, while the MR masks cover the range 480&#8722;1000 nm with a resolution\n          <i>R</i>&#160;=&#160;580. </p>\n<p>We used VIPGI (<a name=\"InR184\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R184\">Scodeggio et al. 2005</a>) for the\n        spectroscopic data reduction. We assigned a Quality Flag (QF) to each redshift, which\n        qualitatively indicates the reliability of a redshift measurement. We define four redshift\n        quality classes: &#8220;secure&#8221; (QF = 3), &#8220;likely&#8221; (QF = 2), &#8220;insecure&#8221; (QF = 1), and &#8220;based on a\n        single-emission-line&#8221; (QF = 9). To assess the reliability of these four quality classes we\n        compared pairs of duplicate observations having at least one secure measurement. Thus, we\n        could quantify the reliability of each quality class as follows: redshifts with QF = 3 are\n        correct with a probability of &gt;99.99%, QF = 9 with ~92% probability,\n        QF = 2 with ~75% probability, and QF=1 with &lt;40% probability. We do\n        not consider QF = 1 redshifts in this paper. </p>\n<p>Additional spectra were taken from <a name=\"InR112\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R112\">Lamareille et al.\n          (2006)</a> (3 objects), <a name=\"InR101\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R101\">Jones et al. (2004)</a>\n        (1), <a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a> (25), and Daniel Kelson\n        (21 observed with IMACS-GISMO at the <i>Magellan </i>telescope, priv. comm.).\n        Archival data from the programs 169.A-0595 (PI: Hans B&#246;hringer; 5 LR-Blue masks) and\n        082.A-0922 (PI: Mike Lerchster, 1 LR-Red mask), for 952 spectra in the cluster field were\n        reduced following the same procedure used for our new CLASH-VLT data, using the appropriate\n        calibrations. </p>\n<p>The final data-set contains 2749 objects with reliable redshift estimates, of which 2513\n        have <i>z</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;0, 18% of them obtained in MR mode.\n        Repeated measurements of the same spectra were used to estimate the average error on the\n        radial velocities, 75 (153) km s<sup>-1</sup> for the spectra observed with the MR (LR,\n        respectively) grism. The average error is sufficiently small not to affect our dynamical\n        analysis, given the large velocity dispersion of the cluster. Full details on the\n        spectroscopic sample observations and data-reduction will be given in Rosati et al. (in\n        prep.). </p>\n<p>Photometric data were derived from Suprime-Cam observations at the prime focus of the\n        Subaru telescope, in five bands\n            (<i>BV</i><i>R</i><sub><i>c</i></sub><i>I</i><sub><i>c</i></sub><i>z</i>&#8242;,\n        see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>). Full details on the derivation of the\n        photometric catalog used in this paper will be given in Mercurio et al. (in prep.). </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>2.1. Cluster membership: the spectroscopic sample</h3>\n<p>Several methods exist to identify cluster members in a spectroscopic data-set (see <a name=\"InR212\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R212\">Wojtak et al. 2007</a>, and references therein). Most of\n          them are based on the location of galaxies in projected phase-space<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#FN6\">3</a></sup>, <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>. For the cluster\n          center we choose the position of the Brightest Cluster Galaxy (BCG,\n                <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq42.png\"></span>). The BCG position practically\n          coincides with the X-ray peak position and the center of mass determined by the\n          gravitational lensing analysis (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>), as all these\n          three positions are within 13 kpc from each other. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a>\n              <p>Histogram of redshifts in the cluster area. The red, hatched histogram shows the\n                main cluster peak identified by the P+G method.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Here we consider two methods to assign the cluster membership, the method of <a name=\"InR73\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R73\">Fadda et al. (1996)</a>, that we call &#8220;P+G&#8221; (Peak+Gap), and\n          the &#8220;Clean&#8221; method of <a name=\"InR134\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">Mamon et al. (2013)</a>. The two\n          methods are very different; in particular, unlike the Clean method, the P+G method does\n          not make any assumption about the cluster mass profile. In both methods the main peak in\n          the <i>z</i>-distribution is identified. For this, P+G uses an algorithm based\n          on adaptive kernels (<a name=\"InR162\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R162\">Pisani 1993</a>), and Clean uses\n          the weighted gaps in the velocity distribution. After the main peak identification (shown\n          in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F1\">1</a>) P+G considers galaxies in moving,\n          overlapping radial bins to reject those that are separated from the main cluster body by a\n          sufficiently large velocity gap (we choose &#916;<i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>&#160;=&#160;800 km\n            s<sup>-1</sup>). The Clean method uses a robust estimate of the cluster line-of-sight\n          velocity dispersion, <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>, to guess the cluster mass using a\n          scaling relation. It then adopts the NFW profile, the theoretical <i>cMr</i> of\n            <a name=\"InR129\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R129\">Macci&#242; et al. (2008)</a>, and the velocity\n          anisotropy profile model of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R133\">Mamon et al. (2010)</a>,\n          to predict <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>(<i>R</i>) and to iteratively reject\n          galaxies with\n            |<i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>|&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&gt;&#160;2.7&#160;<i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>\n          at any radius. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a>\n              <p><i>Top panel</i>: galaxies in the projected phase-space diagram,\n                  <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>. Black dots represent galaxies\n                identified as cluster members by both the P+G and Clean algorithms. Open circles\n                represent galaxies identified as cluster members by the P+G algorithm only. Squares\n                represent galaxies identified as cluster members by the Clean algorithm only.\n                Crosses represent noncluster members. <i>Bottom panel</i>: cluster members\n                selected with the P+G method in the projected phase-space diagram,\n                  <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>. Red circles represent passive\n                galaxies, blue stars represent SF galaxies. In both panels the vertical (magenta)\n                line indicates <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>, i.e. the\n                  <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> value obtained by scaling the\n                  <i>r</i><sub>&#916;</sub> estimate of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> at &#916;&#160;=&#160;200, using their best-fit NFW profile.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F2\">2</a> (top panel) we show the\n            <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub> cluster diagram, with the cluster\n          members selected by the two methods. The P+G and Clean method select 592 and 602 cluster\n          members, respectively. This is one of the largest spectroscopic sample for members of a\n          single cluster, and the largest at <i>z</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;0.4. There\n          are 590 members in common between the two methods, meaning that only two P+G members are\n          not selected by the Clean method, while 12 Clean members are not selected by the P+G\n          method. Given that the two methods are very different, these differences can be considered\n          quite marginal. Since one of our aims is to determine the cluster mass profile, we prefer\n          to base our analysis on the sample of members defined with the P+G method, because, at\n          variance with the Clean method, it requires no a priori assumptions about the cluster mass\n          profile. In Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S17\">A</a> we show that our results are\n          little affected if we choose the Clean membership definition instead. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a>\n              <p>Values of the line-of-sight velocity dispersions, <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>,\n                and of the best-fit parameters of the galaxy number density profiles,\n                  <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>).</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Using the P+G members, we estimate the cluster mean<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#FN7\">4</a></sup>\n          redshift <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq65.png\"></span>. The cluster velocity\n          dispersion is given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a> with\n            1<i>&#963;</i> errors. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a>\n              <p>Line-of-sight velocity dispersion profiles of cluster members (using the P+G\n                identification method). Black filled dots: all galaxies; red circles: passive\n                galaxies; blue stars: SF galaxies. 1<i>&#963;</i> error bars are shown. The\n                vertical magenta dashed line indicates\n                  <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Since the velocity distribution of late-type/blue/active galaxies in clusters is\n          different from that of early-type/red/passive galaxies and characterized by a larger\n            <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> (at least in nearby clusters; <a name=\"InR196\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R196\">Tammann 1972</a>; <a name=\"InR147\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R147\">Moss &amp; Dickens\n            1977</a>; <a name=\"InR190\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R190\">Sodr&#233; et al. 1989</a>; <a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R35\">Biviano et al. 1992</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R36\">1997</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R45\">Carlberg et al. 1997b</a>; <a name=\"InR66\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R66\">Einasto et al. 2010</a>), it is worth considering a\n          subsample of red/passive galaxies for an estimate of <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> and,\n          thereby, <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>. To select a subsample of passive galaxies we\n          use their location in a color&#8722;color plot, requiring\n              (<i>m</i><sub><i>V</i></sub>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>I</i></sub>)&#160;&#8804;&#160;&#160;&#8722;10.47&#160;+&#160;5.5&#160;(<i>m</i><sub><i>B</i></sub>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>).\n          This color&#8722;color selection separates two subsamples of high-quality spectrum galaxies\n          showing spectroscopic features typical of a passively-evolving stellar population and,\n          separately, of ongoing star-formation (for details see Mercurio et al., in prep.). </p>\n<p>The velocity dispersions of passive and star-forming (SF hereafter) galaxies are not\n          significantly different (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a>). This is also\n          evident from the distribution of the two samples in the\n            <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub> diagram (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F2\">2</a>, bottom panel) and from the <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profiles\n          shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F3\">3</a>. In nearby clusters there is more\n          difference between the <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profiles of the passive and SF\n          galaxy populations, but this difference is known to become less significant in\n            higher-<i>z</i> clusters (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R31\">Biviano &amp;\n            Poggianti 2009</a>, <a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R32\">2010</a>). </p>\n<p>We obtain a first estimate of the cluster <i>M</i><sub>200</sub> and\n            <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> from the <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> estimate of\n          the passive cluster members, following the method of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">Mamon et al. (2013)</a>. We assume that (i) the mass is distributed according to the\n          NFW model; (ii) the NFW concentration parameter is obtained iteratively from the mass\n          estimate itself using the <i>cMr</i> of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R129\">Macci&#242;\n            et al. (2008)</a>; and (iii) the velocity anisotropy profile is that of <a name=\"InR132\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R132\">Mamon &amp; &#321;okas (2005)</a> with a scale radius\n          identical to that of the NFW profile (as found in cluster-mass halos extracted from\n          cosmological numerical simulations, see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R133\">Mamon et al.\n            2010</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">2013</a>). The procedure is iterative\n          and uses the value of <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> re-calculated at each iteration on\n          the members within <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>. We find\n            <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;1.42&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>15</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>,\n          which corresponds to <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;1.98 Mpc. Since\n            <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;&#8733;&#160;<i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>, the\n            <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> uncertainty implies a &#8771;5% formal fractional uncertainty\n          on the <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> estimate, and three times larger on\n            <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>. </p>\n<p>This determination of <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> is based on the assumption that\n          the velocity distribution of passive cluster members is unbiased relative to that of DM\n          particles. Numerical simulations suggest that a bias exists, albeit small (e.g. <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R21\">Berlind et al. 2003</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R37\">Biviano et al. 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR150\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R150\">Munari et al.\n          2013a</a>), so we must take this result with caution. The MAMPOSSt and Caustic methods\n          we will use in the following (see Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S6\">3.1</a> and\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S7\">3.2</a>) are unaffected by this possible systematics. </p>\n<p>Our <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>-based <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> value is very\n          close to that obtained by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> from a gravitational\n          lensing analysis, 1.96 Mpc. We estimate this value using their best-fit NFW\n            <i>M</i><sub>&#916;</sub> and <i>c</i><sub>&#916;</sub> values converted from\n          their adopted &#916;&#160;=&#160;131 to &#916;&#160;=&#160;200 (we do the same for <i>c</i><sub>&#916;</sub>, see\n          Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T3\">3</a>). Hereafter we refer to <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>&#8217;s value of <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> as\n            <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>2.2. Completeness and number density profiles</h3>\n<p>Our spectroscopic sample is not complete down to a given flux. This can be seen in Fig.\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F4\">4</a> where we show the\n              <i>R</i><sub><i>c</i></sub>-band number counts in the cluster\n          virial region (<i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;1.96 Mpc), for all photometric objects, for objects\n          with measured redshifts, and for cluster spectroscopic members (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>). Note that the target selection in the spectroscopic\n          masks is such to span a wide color range, so that the resulting sample does not have any\n          appreciable bias against galaxies of a given type, which span from early-type to actively\n          star-forming. </p>\n<p>The incompleteness of the spectroscopic sample is not relevant for that part of the\n          dynamical analysis which is based on the velocity distribution of cluster members. This\n          distribution can be determined at different radii even with incomplete samples, the only\n          effect of incompleteness being a modulation of the accuracy with which the velocity\n          distribution can be estimated at different radii. </p>\n<p>The incompleteness of the spectroscopic sample can instead affect the determination of\n          the cluster projected number density profile, <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>),\n          which converts to the 3D number density profile <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>) via\n          the Abel integral equation (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R25\">Binney &amp; Tremaine\n            1987</a>). The absolute normalization of the galaxy number density profile\n            <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>) is of no concern, however, for our dynamical\n          analysis, since it is only the logarithmic derivative of\n            <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>) that enters the Jeans equation (see, e.g., Eq.\n          (4) in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R103\">Katgert et al. 2004</a>). Only if the\n          incompleteness of the sample is not the same at all radii must we be concerned. </p>\n<p>Our spectroscopic sample does have a mild radially-dependent incompleteness. This is\n          illustrated in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F5\">5</a> where we show a\n          spectroscopic-completeness map obtained as the ratio of two adaptive-kernel maps of galaxy\n          number densities, one for all the objects with <i>z</i>, and the other for all\n          the photometric objects. In both cases we only consider objects within the magnitude range\n          covered by most of the spectroscopic cluster members,\n              18&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;23. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a>\n              <p><i>R</i><sub>c</sub>-band number counts in the cluster virial region\n                (within a radius <i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;1.96 Mpc) for all photometric objects (black\n                histogram), for objects with measured redshifts (hatched blue histogram), and for\n                cluster spectroscopic members (filled red histogram).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a>\n              <p>Spectroscopic completeness map. This is the ratio of two adaptive-kernel number\n                density maps, one for all the objects with <i>z</i>, and the other for all\n                the photometric objects, both within the magnitude range\n                    18&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;23. Contours are labeled\n                with the completeness levels, and show that the spectroscopic completeness becomes\n                slightly higher closer to the center. The magenta circle represents the virial\n                region with radius\n                  <i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>We need to know the radially-dependent completeness correction with an adequate spatial\n          resolution to correctly sample <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>) at small radii, but\n          increasing the spatial resolution comes at the price of increasing the Poisson noise of\n          the number counts on which we base our completeness estimates. Given that within\n            <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> the spectroscopic completeness\n          varies by less than ~20% (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F5\">5</a>) we can, to first\n          approximation, ignore this mild radially-dependent incompleteness. We therefore determine\n          the galaxy <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>) directly from our spectroscopic sample\n          of members within the virial radius and with magnitudes\n              18&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;23. </p>\n<p>We fit the number density profile of the full sample of cluster members, and, separately,\n          the profiles of the subsamples of passive and SF galaxies (defined in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>), using a Maximum Likelihood technique, which does\n          not require radial binning of the data (<a name=\"InR180\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R180\">Sarazin\n            1980</a>). We fit the data with either a projected NFW model (pNFW hereafter; <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R16\">Bartelmann 1996</a>) or with a King model,\n            <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>)&#160;&#8733;&#160;1/&#160;[1&#160;+&#160;(<i>R</i>/<i>r</i><sub>c</sub>)<sup>2</sup>]\n            (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R107\">King 1962</a>; <a name=\"InR3\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R3\">Adami\n            et al. 1998b</a>). The only free parameter in these fits is the scale radius. The\n          results are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a>. The pNFW model\n          provides a better fit than the King model for the samples of all and passive members,\n          while the King model is preferable to the pNFW model for the sample of SF galaxies. All\n          fits are acceptable within the 46% confidence level, with reduced\n            <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> of 0.9, 0.6, and 0.3, for the populations of all,\n          passive, and SF galaxies, respectively. </p>\n<p>To assess the effect of unaccounted incompleteness bias in our estimates, we now check\n          these results using a nearly complete sample of galaxies. This is the sample of galaxies\n          with available photometric redshifts, <i>z</i><sub>p</sub>. Note that we only\n          use this photometric sample for the determination of\n          <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>). Our dynamical analysis is entirely based on the\n          spectroscopic sample. </p>\n<p>The <i>z</i><sub>p</sub> have been obtained by a method based on neural\n          networks. In particular we used the MultiLayer Perceptron (MLP, <a name=\"InR176\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R176\">Rosenblatt 1957</a>) with Quasi-Newton learning rule. The MLP architecture\n          is one of the most typical feed-forward neural network model. The term feed-forward is\n          used to identify the basic behavior of such neural models, in which the impulse is\n          propagated always in the same direction, e.g. from neuron input layers toward output\n          layers, through one or more hidden layers (the network brain), by combining sums of\n          weights associated to all neurons (except the input layer). Quasi-Newton Algorithms (QNA)\n          are an optimization of learning rule, in particular they are variable metric methods for\n          finding local maxima and minima of functions (<a name=\"InR52\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R52\">Davidon\n            1991</a>).
