The sample of all members obey both theoretical relations for\n          <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n          <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>) within the error bars.\n        Also the subsample of passive members follows the theoretical relations, while the subsample\n        of SF galaxies follows the theoretical relations only at\n          <i>r</i>/<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;&#8818;&#160;0.7. </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F18\">18</a> we show\n          <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) vs. the logarithmic derivative of the mass density\n        profile, <i>&#947;</i>(<i>r</i>), for all, passive, and SF members,\n        separately, and the theoretical <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R87\">Hansen &amp; Moore (2006</a>, see Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#FD2\">2</a>. The theoretical relation is consistent with\n        the data within the observational error bars for the full sample of members. Passive\n        galaxies obey the theoretical <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation very well at\n        all radii. On the other hand, the observed relation for SF galaxies deviates from the\n        theoretical one, especially at large radii, but this deviation is not statistically\n        significant, given the rather large observational uncertainties. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S11\"></a>6. Discussion</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>6.1. The mass profile</h3>\n<p>Using a large spectroscopic sample of ~600 cluster members as tracers of the\n          gravitational potential we have determined the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) of\n          the <i>z</i>&#160;=&#160;0.44 MACS J1206.2-0847 cluster to an accuracy close to that\n          reached by the combined strong+weak lensing analysis of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>, and over a wider radial range, reaching out to 5 Mpc (corresponding to\n            2.5&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>). The determination of a cluster\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) to such a high level of accuracy and over such a\n          wide radial range is unprecedented for this redshift. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F18\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F18.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig18_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F18.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 18</span></a>\n              <p>Relations between <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) and the logarithmic\n                derivative of the total mass density profile,\n                <i>&#947;</i>(<i>r</i>), for all, passive, and SF member galaxies\n                  (<i>top</i>, <i>middle</i>, and <i>bottom panel</i>,\n                respectively), within 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence regions (shaded regions), and\n                the theoretical <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R87\">Hansen &amp; Moore (2006)</a> (dashed line). The\n                vertical lines indicate the location of <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> (dashed) and\n                  <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> (dash-dotted).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>For the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) determination we have used two\n          kinematics-based methods, MAMPOSSt and Caustic. This is the first application of the new\n          MAMPOSSt method to an observed cluster. MAMPOSSt allows to determine\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) in the cluster virial region, where the Caustic\n          method suffers from systematics, and Caustic allows to determine\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) beyond the virial region, where MAMPOSSt is not\n          fully applicable because of possible deviations from dynamical equilibrium. The two\n          methods are therefore complementary. </p>\n<p>The MAMPOSSt analysis indicates that the cluster <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>)\n          is best fitted by the NFW or by the Einasto model, although we cannot reject any of the\n          other mass models we have considered, Hernquist, Burkert, and SIS. The SIS model best-fit\n          requires however a very small value of the core radius (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">2</a>). The Caustic analysis shows that the NFW model provides a reasonable\n          fit at least out to ~2&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>. Beyond that radius the\n          uncertainties in the Caustic <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) determination become\n          very large and constraints on the shape of the mass profile are too loose (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F14\">14</a>). </p>\n<p>Previous analyses of cluster mass profiles traced by galaxy kinematics have generally\n          found good agreement with the NFW model (see the review of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R28\">Biviano 2008</a>, and references therein) as we find for MACS J1206.2-0847. The\n          Burkert model was however found to provide a somewhat better fit to the stacked\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) of the ENACS data-set (<a name=\"InR102\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R102\">Katgert et al. 1998</a>) by <a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R33\">Biviano\n            &amp; Salucci (2004)</a> and cored models were not excluded by the analysis of a\n          cluster sample extracted from the 2dFGRS (<a name=\"InR50\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R50\">Colless et al.\n            2001</a>) by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R29\">Biviano &amp; Girardi (2003)</a>.\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R29\">Biviano &amp; Girardi (2003)</a> have also found\n          the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) slope to be consistent with that of NFW up to\n            ~2<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>; beyond that radius, the slope may become\n          intermediate between those of the NFW and Hernquist models, according to the analysis of\n          the CAIRNS cluster sample (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R174\">Rines et al. 2003</a>).\n          These previous results were based on the combination or averaging of several cluster\n          data-sets, since the individual cluster statistics was insufficient to constrain\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>), unlike in our case. </p>\n<p>The best-fit NFW model obtained by combining the results of the two kinematic methods\n          (via a weighted average) is very close to the best-fit NFW model obtained by the combined\n          strong and weak lensing analysis of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> (see Fig.\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F13\">13</a>). The accuracy level we reach on the\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) parameters is close to that reached by the\n          combined strong and weak lensing analysis. There is also a very good agreement with the\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) estimate within\n            ~<i>r</i><sub>500</sub> obtained by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> using Chandra X-ray data. </p>\n<p>The excellent agreement we have found between the kinematically-derived\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>), the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) from\n          lensing, and the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) from X-ray indicates that our and\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>&#8217;s results are free from possible\n          systematics. It also indicates that MACS J1206.2-0847 is dynamically relaxed. </p>\n<p>The <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>-based <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> estimate is\n          also in agreement with our other estimates (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T3\">3</a>\n          and Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F12\">12</a>). This constrains the velocity\n          dispersion of passive cluster members to be within &#177;&#160;10% of that of DM particles, in\n          agreement with the results of numerical simulations (see, e.g., Fig. 8 in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R150\">Munari et al. 2013a</a>). </p>\n<p>Cluster concentrations may be affected by major mergers (<a name=\"InR95\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R95\">Hoffman et al. 2007</a>) and/or baryon cooling (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R84\">Gnedin et al. 2004</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R63\">Duffy et al. 2010</a>;\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R168\">Rasia et al. 2013</a>) which tends to steepen the\n            <i>cMr</i> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R74\">Fedeli 2012</a>). Early\n          adiabatic compression of galactic DM (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R12\">Barkana &amp;\n            Loeb 2010</a>) can increase the concentration. Dynamical friction acting on orbiting\n          galaxies can pump energy into the diffuse DM component and flatten the inner density slope\n            (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R68\">El-Zant et al. 2004</a>), and this flattening can be\n          interpreted as a decrease in concentration (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R170\">Ricotti et\n            al. 2007</a>). The difference in the <i>cMr</i> of relaxed and unrelaxed\n          halos in simulations suggests that the average effect of mergers on concentrations is not\n          very strong (see, e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R53\">De Boni et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R23\">Bhattacharya et al. 2013</a>, see also Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F12\">12</a>). Baryonic processes appear to have a stronger\n          effect, as can be seen by comparing the <i>cMr</i> of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R53\">De Boni et al. (2013)</a>, obtained on hydrodynamical simulations, and that\n          of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R23\">Bhattacharya et al. (2013)</a>, obtained on DM-only\n          simulations (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F12\">12</a>). </p>\n<p>The <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) of MACS J1206.2-0847 has a concentration\n            <i>c</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;6&#160;&#177;&#160;1, slightly higher than the average for halos at\n          the same <i>z</i> and of the same mass\n            (<i>M</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;(1.4&#160;&#177;&#160;0.2)&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>15</sup>&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>)\n          extracted from cosmological numerical simulations (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R53\">De Boni\n            et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R23\">Bhattacharya et al. 2013</a>),\n          but well within the scatter of the theoretical <i>cMr</i> (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F12\">12</a>). The substantial agreement between the observed and\n          theoretically predicted concentrations argues against an alignment of the cluster\n          line-of-sight and major axis. This is also suggested by the fact that the cluster appears\n          somewhat elongated in projection (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>). </p>\n<p>Our result for <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> is consistent with others obtained from\n          analyses of the kinematics of stacked cluster samples, both at low- (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R103\">Katgert et al. 2004</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R34\">Biviano &amp;\n            Salucci 2006</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R124\">&#321;okas et al. 2006b</a>) and\n          high-redshift (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R31\">Biviano &amp; Poggianti 2009</a>).\n          The analyses of the kinematics of individual clusters have found concentrations both in\n          line (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R124\">&#321;okas et al. 2006b</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R171\">Rines &amp; Diaferio 2006</a>) and above the theoretical expectations\n            (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R122\">&#321;okas &amp; Mamon 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR123\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R123\">&#321;okas et al. 2006a</a>; <a name=\"InR210\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R210\">Wojtak &amp; &#321;okas 2007</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R118\">Lemze et al.\n            2009</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R211\">Wojtak &amp; &#321;okas 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R1\">Abdullah et al. 2011</a>). </p>\n<p>The concentration of cluster galaxies (both all and only the passive ones) in MACS\n          J1206.2-0847 is smaller than that of the total mass. Assuming that light traces mass would\n          then lead to an erroneous mass profile determination. The concentration we find for the\n          passive galaxies,\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>/<i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>&#160;=&#160;3.1&#160;&#177;&#160;0.7,\n          is close to the average found by <a name=\"InR121\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R121\">Lin et al. (2004)</a>\n          for <i>K</i>-band-selected galaxies in nearby clusters,\n            <i>c</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;2.9. The concentration of the\n            <i>luminosity</i> density profile of cluster galaxies is only ~10% higher than\n          the concentration of their number density profile, indicating little evidence for mass\n          segregation. The ratio of the concentrations of the total mass and the passive galaxies is\n          1.8&#160;&#177;&#160;0.4, close to that found by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R31\">Biviano &amp;\n            Poggianti (2009)</a> for a stack of nearby clusters (1.7), but much higher than that\n          found by the same authors for a stack of <i>z</i>&#160;~&#160;0.55 clusters (0.4). Other\n          studies have found this ratio to be closer to unity (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R44\">Carlberg et al. 1997a</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R205\">van der Marel et al.\n            2000</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R29\">Biviano &amp; Girardi 2003</a>;\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R103\">Katgert et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR175\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R175\">Rines et al. 2004</a>). Possibly the relative concentration of total mass\n          and cluster galaxy distribution is related to the assembly history of a cluster or to\n          dynamical processes affecting the survival of galaxies near the center, such as merging\n          with the central BCG or tidal stripping. Extending the analysis presented in this paper to\n          other clusters may help understand the physical origin of the relative concentrations of\n          mass and galaxy distribution in clusters. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>6.2. The velocity anisotropy profiles</h3>\n<p>We have determined the velocity anisotropy profiles,\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>), of passive and SF members, separately, for the\n          first time for an individual cluster. This was done from the inversion of the Jeans\n          equation, using our best guess for <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>), derived from\n          the combination of the best-fit NFW <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) from the\n          lensing analysis of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> within\n              <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> and the Caustic\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) outside. MACS J1206.2-0847 is the\n            highest-<i>z</i> cluster for which <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) has\n          been determined, and one of the few at all redshifts. </p>\n<p>In our analysis we have assumed spherical symmetry. The analysis of numerically simulated\n          halos by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R120\">Lemze et al. (2012)</a> has shown that this\n          assumption has almost no effect on the determination of\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) within the virial radius. </p>\n<p>We have found that the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) of all cluster members is\n          consistent with that of cosmological halos in numerical simulations (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R132\">Mamon &amp; &#321;okas 2005</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R133\">Mamon et\n            al. 2010</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">2013</a>, see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F15\">15</a>, top panel). It is not consistent with isotropy at\n          all radii, but only up to ~<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>, then it increases to more\n          radial anisotropy. </p>\n<p>The <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) for passive and SF cluster members are almost\n          identical (and therefore also almost identical to the\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) of all cluster members). This is quite remarkable\n          given that the two cluster populations have different\n            <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>), i.e. they occupy different regions in the\n          cluster. However, the <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> of the two populations are not\n          significantly different (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a>), and the\n            <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>) and\n            <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>(<i>R</i>) of the two populations combine to\n          produce <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq259.png\"></span> profiles of similar shapes\n          (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F16\">16</a>). Hence the observable that enters the\n          Jeans equation inversion (by which we estimate <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>)) is\n          very similar for the two populations. </p>\n<p>This common shape of the orbital distribution of cluster galaxies could be the result of\n          violent relaxation followed by smooth accretion (<a name=\"InR113\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R113\">Lapi\n            &amp; Cavaliere 2009</a>). Violent relaxation is expected to occur at higher\n          redshifts, and isotropize orbits, and therefore should concern the more central cluster\n          regions. Galaxies that were accreted by the cluster after the end of violent relaxation,\n          would retain their slightly radial orbital distribution, producing the external\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>). Yet another process capable of isotropizing the\n          initial radial orbits of infalling galaxies is radial orbit instability (ROI, see, e.g.,\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R19\">Bellovary et al. 2008</a>). </p>\n<p>To understand which is the physical process that shapes the orbits of galaxies in\n          clusters we must study the evolution of <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>). Most\n          previous observational determinations of <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) have been\n          based on stacked clusters or have been obtained by assuming a fixed model shape of\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>). The whole cluster population has been found to\n          move on either isotropic (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R205\">van der Marel et al.\n            2000</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R174\">Rines et al. 2003</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R98\">Hwang &amp; Lee 2008</a>), or mildly radial orbits\n            (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R124\">&#321;okas et al. 2006b</a>) with a general increase of\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) from nearly isotropic orbits near the center to\n          moderate radial anisotropy outside (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R20\">Benatov et al.\n            2006</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R118\">Lemze et al. 2009</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R211\">Wojtak &amp; &#321;okas 2010</a>), similar to the profile\n          we find for MACS J1206.2-0847. The early-type, red, passive cluster population has\n          generally been found to move on isotropic orbits (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R45\">Carlberg\n            et al. 1997b</a>; <a name=\"InR27\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R27\">Biviano 2002</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R122\">&#321;okas &amp; Mamon 2003</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R103\">Katgert et al. 2004</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R98\">Hwang &amp;\n            Lee 2008</a>), while the late-type, blue, SF cluster population has been found to\n          move on slightly radial orbits (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R30\">Biviano &amp; Katgert\n            2004</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R98\">Hwang &amp; Lee 2008</a>). The\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) of SF galaxies in the nearby clusters analyzed by\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R30\">Biviano &amp; Katgert (2004)</a> is isotropic at\n          radii\n            <i>r</i>&#160;&lt;&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>/2,\n          then it becomes more radial. </p>\n<p>Comparison with the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) of lower-<i>z</i>\n          clusters suggests that passive galaxies undergo evolution of their orbits, more than SF\n          galaxies, and the orbits tend to become more isotropic with time. Our result thus confirms\n          the suggestion of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R31\">Biviano &amp; Poggianti\n            (2009)</a>, which was based on a stacked sample of clusters at\n          <i>z</i>&#160;~&#160;0.5 (see also <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R20\">Benatov et al.\n            2006</a>). Since violent relaxation is a process that occurs on relatively short,\n          dynamical timescales, and at high <i>z</i>, one could argue that the secular\n          evolution of galaxy orbits toward isotropy is related instead to a different process,\n          possibly ROI. At variance with violent relaxation, ROI continues even after the cluster\n          has virialized (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R15\">Barnes et al. 2007</a>). If the ROI\n          timescale is long, this could explain why we see orbital evolution for the passive cluster\n          members, and not for the SF ones, since SF galaxies would have the time to transform into\n          passive before ROI modifies their orbits. </p>\n<p>Another process by which cluster galaxies could undergo orbital evolution is via\n          interaction with the ICM (<a name=\"InR61\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R61\">Dolag et al. 2009</a>). Since\n          this process also quenches star-formation, it could naturally explain why we observe\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) evolution for the quenched (passive) cluster\n          galaxies, and not for the SF ones. The timescale and importance of this process needs\n          however to be quantified to allow a more relevant comparison with observational results. </p>\n<p>Other results from numerical simulations are contradictory on the topic of\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) evolution. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R120\">Lemze\n            et al. (2012)</a> do not find significant evolution of\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) with redshift. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R150\">Munari et al. (2013a)</a> finds that <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) for\n          massive clusters becomes mildly more radial at higher redshift. Their result is consistent\n          with that of <a name=\"InR209\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R209\">Wetzel (2011)</a> who finds that the\n          orbits of satellites at the moment of their infall within larger host halos are more\n          radial at higher <i>z</i>. On the other hand, <a name=\"InR99\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R99\">Iannuzzi &amp; Dolag (2012)</a> find the opposite redshift trend. </p>\n<p>To better understand the issue of <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) evolution, one\n          needs a much larger sample of clusters at different redshifts. There is considerable\n          variance in the shapes of the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) of cluster-size halos\n          extracted from numerical simulations, even if located at the same <i>z</i> (see,\n          e.g., Fig. 1 in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">Mamon et al. 2013</a>). Possibly, the\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) shape is related to the shape of\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>), and one cannot treat them separately. Below, we\n          discuss this point in detail. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S14\"></a>6.3. The pseudo-phase-space density profiles</h3>\n<p>In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S13\">6.2</a> we have argued for possible mechanisms\n          capable of explaining the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) of different cluster\n          populations. Combining our knowledge of <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) can shed more light on this topic. For the first\n          time ever, we have determined <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>),\n              <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>), and the\n            <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation observationally, separately for all,\n          passive, and SF cluster members. All cluster members, and also, separately, the subsamples\n          of passive members, obey the theoretical relations within the observational error bars\n          (see Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F17\">17</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F18\">18</a>). Only for SF members there is some tension between the observed and\n          theoretical relations, even if only at large radii,\n            &#8819;0.7&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>. </p>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R55\">Dehnen &amp; McLaughlin (2005)</a> have shown\n          that, given the <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation and the Jeans equation\n          for dynamical equilibrium,\n            <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>) is a power-law in\n            <i>r</i>, with an exponent related to <i>&#946;</i>(0). Based on their\n          finding <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R55\">Dehnen &amp; McLaughlin (2005)</a> argue as\n          follows. Violent relaxation would tend to create a scale-invariant phase-space density\n          (since the process is driven by gravity alone), hence\n              <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>)&#160;&#8733;&#160;<i>r</i><sup><i>&#945;</i></sup>.\n          Dynamical equilibrium would then force <i>&#945;</i> to approach a critical value,\n          from which results the particular form of the <i>&#961;</i>(<i>r</i>) of\n          cosmological halos. A value <i>&#946;</i>(0)&#160;&#8771;&#160;0 with radially increasing\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) gives the <i>&#945;</i> observed in\n          numerical simulations. The form of <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) could therefore\n          result from the halo violent relaxation followed by its dynamical equilibrium (<a name=\"InR86\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R86\">Hansen 2009</a>). </p>\n<p>If this argumentation is correct, passive members of MACS J1206.2-0847 have undergone\n          violent relaxation and have reached dynamical equilibrium, while SF members seem to have\n          not, although the current uncertainties are still rather large. Moreover, one would be\n          tempted to conclude that baryonic processes are not particularly important in shaping the\n          dynamical structure of galaxy clusters, since they are unable to change the\n            <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) of galaxies that have undergone violent\n          relaxation. </p>\n<p>Comparison of the <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n              <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>) for a sample of\n          clusters at different redshifts is needed for further insight. To our knowledge, there is\n          only another cluster for which a similar analysis is being done (<a name=\"InR151\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R151\">Munari et al. 2013b</a>). Also in this nearby (<i>z</i>&#160;=&#160;0.09)\n          cluster, the <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) of red galaxies is in agreement with\n          the theoretical prediction, and that of blue galaxies is not. The lack of evolution in the\n            <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) of passive galaxies is perhaps surprising, since\n          SF galaxies become passive with time, and their <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) is\n          different from that of passive galaxies. Perhaps as SF galaxies get quenched, their\n            <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) evolves and approaches the theoretical\n          prediction, but this would contradict the idea that <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>)\n          is shaped by the process of violent relaxation alone. Another possibility is that the\n          fraction of late-quenched galaxies in the spectroscopic data-sets of passive cluster\n          members is small because late-quenched galaxies are fainter than the more pristine cluster\n          passive members. This can happen because of downsizing (e.g. <a name=\"InR157\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R157\">Neistein et al. 2006</a>), or because of the effects of tidal stripping\n          (e.g. <a name=\"InR11\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R11\">Balogh et al. 2002</a>). Drawing conclusions on\n          the basis of only two clusters is however premature. To shed more light on this topic\n            <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) must be determined for more clusters, over a\n          range of redshifts, and for galaxies of different luminosities. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S15\"></a>7. Conclusions</h2>\n<p>We have analyzed the internal dynamics of the MACS J1206.2-0847 cluster at\n          <i>z</i>&#160;=&#160;0.44, based on a large spectroscopic sample of more than 2500\n        galaxies in its field, mostly from VLT/VIMOS data obtained in the context of the ESO Large\n        Programme 186.A-0798. From this sample we have identified ~600 cluster members. This is the\n        largest spectroscopic sample for cluster member galaxies at\n          <i>z</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;0.4, and one of the largest available at any\n          <i>z</i>. Using this sample, we have applied the Caustic and, for the first time\n        on an observed cluster, the MAMPOSSt method, to determine the cluster mass profile,\n          <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>). These two methods do <i>not </i>rely on\n        the assumption that the spatial and/or velocity distributions of cluster galaxies are\n        identical to those of the DM particles. </p>\n<p>We have found an excellent agreement between the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>)\n        determined using the projected phase-space distribution of cluster galaxies and those\n        determined by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>, who used a combined strong and\n        weak gravitational lensing analysis and Chandra X-ray data. This agreement indicates that\n        possible systematic biases in our dynamical analyses have been properly accounted for, and\n        that the cluster is in a relaxed dynamical state. The cluster\n          <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) is best described by a NFW model, but other mass\n        profile models provide acceptable fits to our data. The observed concentration of the\n        best-fit NFW model is slightly above current theoretical predictions, but not significantly\n        so. The spatial distribution of all and passive cluster members is less centrally\n        concentrated than the total mass. Using the velocity dispersion of passive cluster members\n        to estimate the cluster mass gives a value in agreement with those obtained by the other,\n        more sophisticated, analyses. This suggests that the bias between the velocity dispersion of\n        passive cluster members and DM particles is small, &#8818;10%. </p>\n<p>We have defined a fiducial <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) from the combination of\n        those obtained with the lensing and kinematic analyses, spanning a radial range from the\n        center to ~5 Mpc (corresponding to 2.5&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>). To our\n        knowledge, this is currently the most accurate determination of a cluster\n          <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) over this radial range. We have used it to invert\n        the Jeans equation and determine the velocity anisotropy profiles,\n          <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>), for all cluster members, and, separately, for\n        passive and SF cluster members. This is the highest-<i>z</i> individual cluster\n        for which <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) has been determined so far, and the only\n        one for which <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) has been determined separately for both\n        passive and SF galaxies. We have found almost identical velocity anisotropy profiles for the\n        different cluster galaxy populations, isotropic near the center (within\n          ~<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>) and increasingly radially anisotropic outside. This\n        profile resembles that of DM particles in halos extracted from cosmological numerical\n        simulations. Comparison with nearby clusters suggests evolution of the orbital profile of\n        passive cluster members, but the physical mechanism driving this evolution remains to be\n        identified. </p>\n<p>From the mass density profile and <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>), thanks to the\n        quality of our <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and the size of our spectroscopic\n        data-set, we have been able to determine the pseudo phase-space density profiles\n          <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n          <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>) and the\n          <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation. These are the first observational\n        determinations of these profiles and relation for a galaxy cluster. They are consistent with\n        the theoretical expectations in particular for the passive cluster members. This is probably\n        an indication that these galaxies were in the cluster at the time of violent relaxation.\n        Marginal deviation from the theoretical relations is observed instead for the SF cluster\n        members, suggesting that they are a more recently accreted population. </p>\n<p>The cluster studied in this paper is part of a sample of 14 clusters from the CLASH-VLT\n        Large Programme with the VIMOS spectrograph, which we expect to be completed in 2014. In\n        this paper we have shown that with a spectroscopic sample of this size it is possible to\n        constrain a cluster <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) to an accuracy similar to that\n        achievable by a detailed, combined strong + weak lensing analysis. It is also possible to\n        constrain the orbits of different cluster galaxy populations in a non parametric way by\n        direct inversion of the Jeans equation. Combining results from\n          <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) it is\n        possible to test dynamical relations that inform us on the way cosmological halos evolve and\n        organize internally. We will extend this analysis to all the CLASH clusters with sufficient\n        spectroscopic coverage in the near future, and this will allow us to explore the variance in\n        the cluster dynamical states, the <i>cMr</i> for the total mass and the different\n        galaxy populations, and the universality of the <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n          <i>&#946;</i>-<i>&#947;</i> dynamical relations. Stacking dynamically-relaxed\n        clusters together could in the end even allow us to constrain the equation of state of DM by\n        comparison of the kinematically-derived and lensing-derived mass profiles (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R71\">Faber &amp; Visser 2006</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R186\">Serra &amp; Dom&#237;nguez Romero 2011</a>). </p>\n    <hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN4\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The radius <i>r</i><sub>&#916;</sub> is the radius of a sphere with mass\n          overdensity &#916; times the critical density at the cluster redshift. Throughout this paper we\n          refer to the &#916;&#160;=&#160;200 radius as the &#8220;virial radius&#8221;, <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN5\"></a><sup>2</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The mass <i>M</i><sub>&#916;</sub> is directly connected to\n            <i>r</i><sub>&#916;</sub> via <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq309.png\"></span>, where\n            <i>H</i><sub><i>z</i></sub> is the Hubble constant at the redshift,\n            <i>z</i>, of the halo. Throughout this paper we refer to the &#916;&#160;=&#160;200 mass as\n          the &#8220;virial mass&#8221;, <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN6\"></a><sup>3</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> We call <i>R</i> (resp. <i>r</i>) the projected (resp. 3D) radial\n          distance from the cluster center (we assume spherical symmetry in the dynamical analyses).\n          The rest-frame velocity is defined as <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq311.png\"></span>, where\n                <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq312.png\"></span> is the mean\n          cluster redshift, redefined at each new iteration of the membership determination.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN7\"></a><sup>4</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Throughout this paper we use the robust biweight estimator for computing averages and\n          dispersions (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R18\">Beers et al. 1990</a>), and Eqs. (15) and\n          (16) in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R18\">Beers et al. (1990)</a> for computing their\n          uncertainties.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN8\"></a><sup>5</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The weak lensing solution we display here is the one obtained by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> after removal of an extended large-scale structure feature\n          contaminating the external regions of the cluster along the line-of-sight. See <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> for details.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN9\"></a><sup>6</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Note that in this figure we show the non parametric solution for\n            <i>M</i><sub>p</sub>(<i>R</i>) obtained by the lensing technique,\n          not the pNFW fit.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN10\"></a><sup>7</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> Dynamical relaxation of the cluster may not hold beyond\n          <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>, so we prefer not to use the kinematics of cluster\n          galaxies at larger radii in the Jeans equation inversion.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN11\"></a><sup>8</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"> The derivation of <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) for DM particles done by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R88\">Hansen &amp; Piffaretti (2007)</a> is based on the\n          strong assumption that the DM &#8220;temperature&#8221; is identical to that of the hot intra-cluster\n          gas at all radii, an assumption that cannot be verified observationally. A similar\n          approach was followed by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R119\">Lemze et al. (2011)</a>,\n          except that they used galaxies rather than intra-cluster gas for their derivation of the\n          DM <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>). Their approach is more appealing than that of\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R88\">Hansen &amp; Piffaretti (2007)</a> because both\n          DM particles and galaxies are collisionless, while gas is not.</p>\n</div></div>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ack\"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>\n<p>We wish to thank Colin Norman for originally suggesting one of us (AB) to determine the\n        pseudo-phase-space density profiles. We also thank Stefano Borgani, Gary Mamon, Giuseppe\n        Murante, Tommaso Treu, and the referee, Elmo Tempel, for useful suggestions and discussions,\n        and Hans B&#246;hringer for providing phase 2 information on his VIMOS programme (169.A-0595)\n        also used in this study. This research is partly supported by the PRIN INAF 2010:\n        &#8220;Architecture and Tomography of Galaxy Clusters&#8221;. P.R. and I.B. acknowledge partial support\n        by the DFG cluster of excellence Origin and Structure of the Universe (<a href=\"http://www.universe-cluster.de\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.universe-cluster.de</a>). R.D. gratefully acknowledges the support\n        provided by the BASAL Center for Astrophysics and Associated Technologies (CATA), and by\n        FONDECYT grant N. 1130528. </p>\n    <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ref\"></a>References</h2>\n    <div id=\"content\">\n        <ol class=\"references\">\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R1\"></a>Abdullah, M.                             \t\t\n                \n                                    <a            <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                    <li>\n                <a                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                </ol>\n    </div>\n\n  <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S16\"></a>Online material</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>Appendix A: The effects of different cluster membership definitions</h3>\n<a name=\"SD1\"></a><p>The determinations of <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n              <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) described in Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S5\">3</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S9\">4</a> are based, at least in\n            part, on the sample of cluster members defined by the P+G procedure (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>). Here we examine how a different cluster\n            membership definition affects our results. For this, we here consider the membership\n            definition obtained with the Clean method instead of the P+G method. The two methods use\n            very different approaches for the identification of cluster members, as described in\n            Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>. </p>\n<p>In Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T4\">A.1</a> we list the fractional differences\n            and associated 1<i>&#963;</i> uncertainties of the\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> and\n              <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> determinations obtained by using the\n            two samples of cluster members identified with the P+G and the Clean methods. The\n            effects of changing the method of membership selection are marginal, as all changes are\n            within 1<i>&#963;</i>. </p>\n<p>\n            <a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table A.1</span></a>\n                <p>Effects of changing the member selection method (Clean vs. P+G).</p>\n              </div></div>\n          </p>\n<p>The <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> estimates are all slightly increased when adopting\n            the Clean method instead of the P+G method, and this happens because of the 8 galaxies\n            with high absolute values of <i>v</i><sub>rf</sub> near the cluster center\n            selected as members by the Clean method but not by the P+G method (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F2\">2</a>). Since 7 of these 8 galaxies are passive, the\n            effects of the different membership selection are stronger on the quantities derived\n            using only passive galaxies. </p>\n<p>The inclusion of these 8 galaxies in the sample of cluster members causes a higher\n            velocity dispersion estimate near the center, and therefore a steeper\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profile. To accommodate for the steeper\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profile near the center, the MAMPOSSt analysis forces\n            more concentrated mass profiles, with 20&#8211;25% smaller <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>\n            estimates. However, given the large uncertainties on the <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>\n            estimates these changes are far from being significant. The Caustic\n              <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) estimate is less affected, because i) it is\n            only partially based on the membership selection within the virial radius, and ii) it\n            uses all galaxies (and not only members) also beyond the virial radius. </p>\n<p>The <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> estimates depend very little on\n            which membership selection is chosen, because i) they are based not only on the sample\n            of spectroscopic members but also on the sample of\n            <i>z</i><sub>p</sub>-selected members; and ii) the inclusion of the 8\n            additional members near the center has a smaller impact on\n              <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>) than it has on\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>(<i>R</i>). </p>\n<p>Given the marginal changes in the MAMPOSSt and Caustic estimates of\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>, using the\n            Clean-based membership determination instead of the P+G-based one, we still find\n            consistency between the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) obtained via the MAMPOSSt\n            and Caustic method and that of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>. As a\n            consequence, we would still adopt the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> within\n                <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> and the Caustic\n              <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) at larger radii, and the resulting\n              <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) would be almost identical to the one we adopted\n            using the P+G membership determination (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S8\">3.3</a>). </p>\n<p>\n            \n            <a name=\"F19\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F19.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig19_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F19.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. A.1</span></a>\n                <p>Difference of the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) determined using the\n                  Clean and P+G samples of members. The solid (white), dashed (red), and dash-dotted\n                  (cyan) curves are for all, passive, and SF galaxies, respectively.\n                    1<i>&#963;</i> intervals on the differences are shown as shaded regions,\n                  with 45, 0, and 90 degrees orientation of the (gray, orange, blue) shading for\n                  all, passive, and SF galaxies, respectively. </p>\n              </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n          </p>\n<p>The <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) profiles resulting from the inversion of the\n            Jeans equation are marginally affected mostly because of the steepening of the\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profile. Given that the adopted\n              <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) is almost unchanged with respect to the case of\n            P+G membership selection, the steepening of\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>(<i>R</i>) near the center must be\n            compensated by an increased radial anisotropy. This concerns mostly the passive\n            galaxies. The differences between the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) obtained\n            using the Clean-based sample of members and those obtained using the P+G-based sample of\n            members are consistent with zero within 1<i>&#963;</i> for all cluster populations\n            and at all radii (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F19\">A.1</a>). </p>\n<p>We conclude that our results do not change significantly if we use the Clean instead of\n            the P+G method for membership selection. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S18\"></a>Appendix B: Comparison with other cluster mass estimates from the literature</h3>\n<a name=\"SD2\"></a><p>We here compare our results to those obtained by <a name=\"InR76\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R76\">Fo&#235;x\n              et al. (2012)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a>.\n            In both cases their data were of insufficiently quality to constrain both\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>, so we only\n            compare the <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> values. </p>\n<p>The weak lensing <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> estimate of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R76\">Fo&#235;x et al. (2012)</a>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq302.png\"></span>\n            Mpc, is in good agreement with our estimate. </p>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a> have estimated the cluster\n            mass in three ways; i) by strong lensing; ii) by an hydrostatic equilibrium analysis of\n            the X-ray emitting intra-cluster medium; and iii) by the virial theorem. Their strong\n            lensing mass estimate, 1.12&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> within 0.12\n            Mpc from the cluster center, is in agreement with our determinations. By applying a\n            scaling relation to the cluster X-ray temperature <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a> obtain an approximate value of\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>, 2.3&#160;&#160;&#177;&#160;&#160;0.1 Mpc, in disagreement with our\n            estimate. They then estimate the cluster mass within this radius using an isothermal\n              <i>&#946;</i> model profile,\n              1.7&#160;&#177;&#160;1&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>15</sup>&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>. This\n              <i>M</i><sub>200</sub> estimate corresponds to a\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> estimate of 2.1 Mpc, different from their initial\n            estimate, but still above our best estimate. Had they iterated their Eq. (5) they would\n            have obtained a concordant pair of\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>M</i><sub>200</sub>\n            estimates with a final value of <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> of 2.03 Mpc, closer to\n            our best estimate. </p>\n<p>The virial theorem mass estimate of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al.\n              (2009)</a> is instead grossly discrepant with any other estimate discussed so far.\n            This appears to be due to a combination of causes. </p>\n<p>First, their membership selection is too simplistic since it does not take into account\n            the radial position of galaxies. As a consequence, they obtain a much larger velocity\n            dispersion estimate than we do, 1581 km s<sup>-1</sup> (compare to the values in Table\n              <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a>). Their large estimate is also due to the\n            fact that <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> is decreasing with <i>R</i> (see\n            Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F3\">3</a>) and their spectroscopic sample does not\n            reach <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>. Other causes that lead <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a> to overestimate the cluster\n            mass using the virial theorem are the neglect of the surface-pressure term (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R199\">The &amp; White 1986</a>), and the use of a\n            spatially incomplete sample in the estimate of the projected harmonic mean radius (see\n              <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R37\">Biviano et al. 2006</a>). </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"tabs\"></a>All Tables</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a>\n              <p>Values of the line-of-sight velocity dispersions, <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>,\n                and of the best-fit parameters of the galaxy number density profiles,\n                  <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>).</p>\n            <div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2</span></a>\n              <p>Results of the MAMPOSSt analysis.</p>\n            <div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3</span></a>\n              <p>Best-fit dynamical parameters for the NFW <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>)\n                model.</p>\n            <div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T3\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table A.1</span></a>\n                <p>Effects of changing the member selection method (Clean vs. P+G).</p>\n              <div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T4\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"figs\"></a>All Figures</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a>\n              <p>Histogram of redshifts in the cluster area. The red, hatched histogram shows the\n                main cluster peak identified by the P+G method.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a>\n              <p><i>Top panel</i>: galaxies in the projected phase-space diagram,\n                  <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>.
