In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S2\">2</a> we\n        describe the data sample, and the identification of cluster members. We determine the\n        cluster mass profile in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S5\">3</a> and compare our results\n        to theoretical expectations for the <i>cMr</i>. We determine the cluster velocity\n        anisotropy profile in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S9\">4</a>. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S10\">5</a> we test observationally the theoretical\n          <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>),\n          <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>), and\n          <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation. We discuss our results in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S11\">6</a> and provide our conclusions in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S15\">7</a>. In Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S17\">A</a> we\n        show that our results are robust vs. different choices of the method for cluster members\n        identification. In Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S18\">B</a> we compare our results\n        for the cluster mass with previous, less accurate results from the literature. </p>\n<p>Throughout this paper, we adopt <i>H</i><sub>0</sub>&#160;=&#160;70 km s<sup>-1</sup>\n          Mpc<sup>-1</sup>, &#937;<sub>0</sub>&#160;=&#160;0.3, &#937;<sub>&#923;</sub>&#160;=&#160;0.7. At the cluster redshift, 1\n        arcmin corresponds to 0.34 Mpc. Magnitudes are in the AB system. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. The data sample</h2>\n<p>The cluster MACS J1206.2-0847 was observed in 2012 as part of the ESO Large Programme\n        186.A-0798 using VIMOS (<a name=\"InR117\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R117\">Le F&#232;vre et al. 2003</a>) at the\n        ESO VLT. The VIMOS data were acquired using four separate pointings, each with a different\n        quadrant centered on the cluster core. A total of 12 masks were observed (8 LR-Blue masks\n        and 4 MR masks), and each mask was observed for either 3 or 4&#160;&#215;&#160;15 min, for a total of 10.7\n        h exposure time. The LR-Blue masks cover the spectral range 370&#8722;670 nm with a resolution\n          <i>R</i>&#160;=&#160;180, while the MR masks cover the range 480&#8722;1000 nm with a resolution\n          <i>R</i>&#160;=&#160;580. </p>\n<p>We used VIPGI (<a name=\"InR184\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R184\">Scodeggio et al. 2005</a>) for the\n        spectroscopic data reduction. We assigned a Quality Flag (QF) to each redshift, which\n        qualitatively indicates the reliability of a redshift measurement. We define four redshift\n        quality classes: &#8220;secure&#8221; (QF = 3), &#8220;likely&#8221; (QF = 2), &#8220;insecure&#8221; (QF = 1), and &#8220;based on a\n        single-emission-line&#8221; (QF = 9). To assess the reliability of these four quality classes we\n        compared pairs of duplicate observations having at least one secure measurement. Thus, we\n        could quantify the reliability of each quality class as follows: redshifts with QF = 3 are\n        correct with a probability of &gt;99.99%, QF = 9 with ~92% probability,\n        QF = 2 with ~75% probability, and QF=1 with &lt;40% probability. We do\n        not consider QF = 1 redshifts in this paper. </p>\n<p>Additional spectra were taken from <a name=\"InR112\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R112\">Lamareille et al.\n          (2006)</a> (3 objects), <a name=\"InR101\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R101\">Jones et al. (2004)</a>\n        (1), <a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a> (25), and Daniel Kelson\n        (21 observed with IMACS-GISMO at the <i>Magellan </i>telescope, priv. comm.).\n        Archival data from the programs 169.A-0595 (PI: Hans B&#246;hringer; 5 LR-Blue masks) and\n        082.A-0922 (PI: Mike Lerchster, 1 LR-Red mask), for 952 spectra in the cluster field were\n        reduced following the same procedure used for our new CLASH-VLT data, using the appropriate\n        calibrations. </p>\n<p>The final data-set contains 2749 objects with reliable redshift estimates, of which 2513\n        have <i>z</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;0, 18% of them obtained in MR mode.\n        Repeated measurements of the same spectra were used to estimate the average error on the\n        radial velocities, 75 (153) km s<sup>-1</sup> for the spectra observed with the MR (LR,\n        respectively) grism. The average error is sufficiently small not to affect our dynamical\n        analysis, given the large velocity dispersion of the cluster. Full details on the\n        spectroscopic sample observations and data-reduction will be given in Rosati et al. (in\n        prep.). </p>\n<p>Photometric data were derived from Suprime-Cam observations at the prime focus of the\n        Subaru telescope, in five bands\n            (<i>BV</i><i>R</i><sub><i>c</i></sub><i>I</i><sub><i>c</i></sub><i>z</i>&#8242;,\n        see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>). Full details on the derivation of the\n        photometric catalog used in this paper will be given in Mercurio et al. (in prep.). </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>2.1. Cluster membership: the spectroscopic sample</h3>\n<p>Several methods exist to identify cluster members in a spectroscopic data-set (see <a name=\"InR212\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R212\">Wojtak et al. 2007</a>, and references therein). Most of\n          them are based on the location of galaxies in projected phase-space<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#FN6\">3</a></sup>, <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>. For the cluster\n          center we choose the position of the Brightest Cluster Galaxy (BCG,\n                <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq42.png\"></span>). The BCG position practically\n          coincides with the X-ray peak position and the center of mass determined by the\n          gravitational lensing analysis (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>), as all these\n          three positions are within 13 kpc from each other. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a>\n              <p>Histogram of redshifts in the cluster area. The red, hatched histogram shows the\n                main cluster peak identified by the P+G method.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Here we consider two methods to assign the cluster membership, the method of <a name=\"InR73\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R73\">Fadda et al. (1996)</a>, that we call &#8220;P+G&#8221; (Peak+Gap), and\n          the &#8220;Clean&#8221; method of <a name=\"InR134\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">Mamon et al. (2013)</a>. The two\n          methods are very different; in particular, unlike the Clean method, the P+G method does\n          not make any assumption about the cluster mass profile. In both methods the main peak in\n          the <i>z</i>-distribution is identified. For this, P+G uses an algorithm based\n          on adaptive kernels (<a name=\"InR162\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R162\">Pisani 1993</a>), and Clean uses\n          the weighted gaps in the velocity distribution. After the main peak identification (shown\n          in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F1\">1</a>) P+G considers galaxies in moving,\n          overlapping radial bins to reject those that are separated from the main cluster body by a\n          sufficiently large velocity gap (we choose &#916;<i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>&#160;=&#160;800 km\n            s<sup>-1</sup>). The Clean method uses a robust estimate of the cluster line-of-sight\n          velocity dispersion, <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>, to guess the cluster mass using a\n          scaling relation. It then adopts the NFW profile, the theoretical <i>cMr</i> of\n            <a name=\"InR129\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R129\">Macci&#242; et al. (2008)</a>, and the velocity\n          anisotropy profile model of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R133\">Mamon et al. (2010)</a>,\n          to predict <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>(<i>R</i>) and to iteratively reject\n          galaxies with\n            |<i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>|&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&gt;&#160;2.7&#160;<i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>\n          at any radius. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a>\n              <p><i>Top panel</i>: galaxies in the projected phase-space diagram,\n                  <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>. Black dots represent galaxies\n                identified as cluster members by both the P+G and Clean algorithms. Open circles\n                represent galaxies identified as cluster members by the P+G algorithm only. Squares\n                represent galaxies identified as cluster members by the Clean algorithm only.\n                Crosses represent noncluster members. <i>Bottom panel</i>: cluster members\n                selected with the P+G method in the projected phase-space diagram,\n                  <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub>. Red circles represent passive\n                galaxies, blue stars represent SF galaxies. In both panels the vertical (magenta)\n                line indicates <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>, i.e. the\n                  <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> value obtained by scaling the\n                  <i>r</i><sub>&#916;</sub> estimate of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> at &#916;&#160;=&#160;200, using their best-fit NFW profile.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F2\">2</a> (top panel) we show the\n            <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub> cluster diagram, with the cluster\n          members selected by the two methods. The P+G and Clean method select 592 and 602 cluster\n          members, respectively. This is one of the largest spectroscopic sample for members of a\n          single cluster, and the largest at <i>z</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;0.4. There\n          are 590 members in common between the two methods, meaning that only two P+G members are\n          not selected by the Clean method, while 12 Clean members are not selected by the P+G\n          method. Given that the two methods are very different, these differences can be considered\n          quite marginal. Since one of our aims is to determine the cluster mass profile, we prefer\n          to base our analysis on the sample of members defined with the P+G method, because, at\n          variance with the Clean method, it requires no a priori assumptions about the cluster mass\n          profile. In Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S17\">A</a> we show that our results are\n          little affected if we choose the Clean membership definition instead. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a>\n              <p>Values of the line-of-sight velocity dispersions, <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>,\n                and of the best-fit parameters of the galaxy number density profiles,\n                  <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>).</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Using the P+G members, we estimate the cluster mean<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#FN7\">4</a></sup>\n          redshift <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq65.png\"></span>. The cluster velocity\n          dispersion is given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a> with\n            1<i>&#963;</i> errors. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a>\n              <p>Line-of-sight velocity dispersion profiles of cluster members (using the P+G\n                identification method). Black filled dots: all galaxies; red circles: passive\n                galaxies; blue stars: SF galaxies. 1<i>&#963;</i> error bars are shown. The\n                vertical magenta dashed line indicates\n                  <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>Since the velocity distribution of late-type/blue/active galaxies in clusters is\n          different from that of early-type/red/passive galaxies and characterized by a larger\n            <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> (at least in nearby clusters; <a name=\"InR196\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R196\">Tammann 1972</a>; <a name=\"InR147\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R147\">Moss &amp; Dickens\n            1977</a>; <a name=\"InR190\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R190\">Sodr&#233; et al. 1989</a>; <a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R35\">Biviano et al. 1992</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R36\">1997</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R45\">Carlberg et al. 1997b</a>; <a name=\"InR66\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R66\">Einasto et al. 2010</a>), it is worth considering a\n          subsample of red/passive galaxies for an estimate of <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> and,\n          thereby, <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>. To select a subsample of passive galaxies we\n          use their location in a color&#8722;color plot, requiring\n              (<i>m</i><sub><i>V</i></sub>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>I</i></sub>)&#160;&#8804;&#160;&#160;&#8722;10.47&#160;+&#160;5.5&#160;(<i>m</i><sub><i>B</i></sub>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>).\n          This color&#8722;color selection separates two subsamples of high-quality spectrum galaxies\n          showing spectroscopic features typical of a passively-evolving stellar population and,\n          separately, of ongoing star-formation (for details see Mercurio et al., in prep.). </p>\n<p>The velocity dispersions of passive and star-forming (SF hereafter) galaxies are not\n          significantly different (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a>). This is also\n          evident from the distribution of the two samples in the\n            <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub> diagram (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F2\">2</a>, bottom panel) and from the <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profiles\n          shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F3\">3</a>. In nearby clusters there is more\n          difference between the <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profiles of the passive and SF\n          galaxy populations, but this difference is known to become less significant in\n            higher-<i>z</i> clusters (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R31\">Biviano &amp;\n            Poggianti 2009</a>, <a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R32\">2010</a>). </p>\n<p>We obtain a first estimate of the cluster <i>M</i><sub>200</sub> and\n            <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> from the <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> estimate of\n          the passive cluster members, following the method of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">Mamon et al. (2013)</a>. We assume that (i) the mass is distributed according to the\n          NFW model; (ii) the NFW concentration parameter is obtained iteratively from the mass\n          estimate itself using the <i>cMr</i> of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R129\">Macci&#242;\n            et al. (2008)</a>; and (iii) the velocity anisotropy profile is that of <a name=\"InR132\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R132\">Mamon &amp; &#321;okas (2005)</a> with a scale radius\n          identical to that of the NFW profile (as found in cluster-mass halos extracted from\n          cosmological numerical simulations, see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R133\">Mamon et al.\n            2010</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">2013</a>). The procedure is iterative\n          and uses the value of <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> re-calculated at each iteration on\n          the members within <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>. We find\n            <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;1.42&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>15</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>,\n          which corresponds to <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;=&#160;1.98 Mpc. Since\n            <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;&#8733;&#160;<i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>, the\n            <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> uncertainty implies a &#8771;5% formal fractional uncertainty\n          on the <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> estimate, and three times larger on\n            <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>. </p>\n<p>This determination of <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> is based on the assumption that\n          the velocity distribution of passive cluster members is unbiased relative to that of DM\n          particles. Numerical simulations suggest that a bias exists, albeit small (e.g. <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R21\">Berlind et al. 2003</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R37\">Biviano et al. 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR150\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R150\">Munari et al.\n          2013a</a>), so we must take this result with caution. The MAMPOSSt and Caustic methods\n          we will use in the following (see Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S6\">3.1</a> and\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S7\">3.2</a>) are unaffected by this possible systematics. </p>\n<p>Our <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>-based <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> value is very\n          close to that obtained by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> from a gravitational\n          lensing analysis, 1.96 Mpc. We estimate this value using their best-fit NFW\n            <i>M</i><sub>&#916;</sub> and <i>c</i><sub>&#916;</sub> values converted from\n          their adopted &#916;&#160;=&#160;131 to &#916;&#160;=&#160;200 (we do the same for <i>c</i><sub>&#916;</sub>, see\n          Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T3\">3</a>). Hereafter we refer to <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>&#8217;s value of <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> as\n            <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>2.2. Completeness and number density profiles</h3>\n<p>Our spectroscopic sample is not complete down to a given flux. This can be seen in Fig.\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F4\">4</a> where we show the\n              <i>R</i><sub><i>c</i></sub>-band number counts in the cluster\n          virial region (<i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;1.96 Mpc), for all photometric objects, for objects\n          with measured redshifts, and for cluster spectroscopic members (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>). Note that the target selection in the spectroscopic\n          masks is such to span a wide color range, so that the resulting sample does not have any\n          appreciable bias against galaxies of a given type, which span from early-type to actively\n          star-forming. </p>\n<p>The incompleteness of the spectroscopic sample is not relevant for that part of the\n          dynamical analysis which is based on the velocity distribution of cluster members. This\n          distribution can be determined at different radii even with incomplete samples, the only\n          effect of incompleteness being a modulation of the accuracy with which the velocity\n          distribution can be estimated at different radii. </p>\n<p>The incompleteness of the spectroscopic sample can instead affect the determination of\n          the cluster projected number density profile, <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>),\n          which converts to the 3D number density profile <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>) via\n          the Abel integral equation (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R25\">Binney &amp; Tremaine\n            1987</a>). The absolute normalization of the galaxy number density profile\n            <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>) is of no concern, however, for our dynamical\n          analysis, since it is only the logarithmic derivative of\n            <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>) that enters the Jeans equation (see, e.g., Eq.\n          (4) in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R103\">Katgert et al. 2004</a>). Only if the\n          incompleteness of the sample is not the same at all radii must we be concerned. </p>\n<p>Our spectroscopic sample does have a mild radially-dependent incompleteness. This is\n          illustrated in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F5\">5</a> where we show a\n          spectroscopic-completeness map obtained as the ratio of two adaptive-kernel maps of galaxy\n          number densities, one for all the objects with <i>z</i>, and the other for all\n          the photometric objects. In both cases we only consider objects within the magnitude range\n          covered by most of the spectroscopic cluster members,\n              18&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;23. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a>\n              <p><i>R</i><sub>c</sub>-band number counts in the cluster virial region\n                (within a radius <i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;1.96 Mpc) for all photometric objects (black\n                histogram), for objects with measured redshifts (hatched blue histogram), and for\n                cluster spectroscopic members (filled red histogram).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a>\n              <p>Spectroscopic completeness map. This is the ratio of two adaptive-kernel number\n                density maps, one for all the objects with <i>z</i>, and the other for all\n                the photometric objects, both within the magnitude range\n                    18&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;23. Contours are labeled\n                with the completeness levels, and show that the spectroscopic completeness becomes\n                slightly higher closer to the center. The magenta circle represents the virial\n                region with radius\n                  <i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>We need to know the radially-dependent completeness correction with an adequate spatial\n          resolution to correctly sample <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>) at small radii, but\n          increasing the spatial resolution comes at the price of increasing the Poisson noise of\n          the number counts on which we base our completeness estimates. Given that within\n            <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> the spectroscopic completeness\n          varies by less than ~20% (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F5\">5</a>) we can, to first\n          approximation, ignore this mild radially-dependent incompleteness. We therefore determine\n          the galaxy <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>) directly from our spectroscopic sample\n          of members within the virial radius and with magnitudes\n              18&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;23. </p>\n<p>We fit the number density profile of the full sample of cluster members, and, separately,\n          the profiles of the subsamples of passive and SF galaxies (defined in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>), using a Maximum Likelihood technique, which does\n          not require radial binning of the data (<a name=\"InR180\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R180\">Sarazin\n            1980</a>). We fit the data with either a projected NFW model (pNFW hereafter; <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R16\">Bartelmann 1996</a>) or with a King model,\n            <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>)&#160;&#8733;&#160;1/&#160;[1&#160;+&#160;(<i>R</i>/<i>r</i><sub>c</sub>)<sup>2</sup>]\n            (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R107\">King 1962</a>; <a name=\"InR3\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R3\">Adami\n            et al. 1998b</a>). The only free parameter in these fits is the scale radius. The\n          results are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a>. The pNFW model\n          provides a better fit than the King model for the samples of all and passive members,\n          while the King model is preferable to the pNFW model for the sample of SF galaxies. All\n          fits are acceptable within the 46% confidence level, with reduced\n            <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> of 0.9, 0.6, and 0.3, for the populations of all,\n          passive, and SF galaxies, respectively. </p>\n<p>To assess the effect of unaccounted incompleteness bias in our estimates, we now check\n          these results using a nearly complete sample of galaxies. This is the sample of galaxies\n          with available photometric redshifts, <i>z</i><sub>p</sub>. Note that we only\n          use this photometric sample for the determination of\n          <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>). Our dynamical analysis is entirely based on the\n          spectroscopic sample. </p>\n<p>The <i>z</i><sub>p</sub> have been obtained by a method based on neural\n          networks. In particular we used the MultiLayer Perceptron (MLP, <a name=\"InR176\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R176\">Rosenblatt 1957</a>) with Quasi-Newton learning rule. The MLP architecture\n          is one of the most typical feed-forward neural network model. The term feed-forward is\n          used to identify the basic behavior of such neural models, in which the impulse is\n          propagated always in the same direction, e.g. from neuron input layers toward output\n          layers, through one or more hidden layers (the network brain), by combining sums of\n          weights associated to all neurons (except the input layer). Quasi-Newton Algorithms (QNA)\n          are an optimization of learning rule, in particular they are variable metric methods for\n          finding local maxima and minima of functions (<a name=\"InR52\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R52\">Davidon\n            1991</a>). The model based on this learning rule and on the MLP network topology is\n          then called MLPQNA (for details on the method see <a name=\"InR38\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R38\">Brescia\n            et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR47\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R47\">Cavuoti et al. 2012</a>). </p>\n<p>This method was applied to the whole data-set of&#8201;~34&#8201;000 objects with available and\n          reliable\n            <i>BV</i><i>R</i><sub><i>c</i></sub><i>I</i><sub><i>c</i></sub><i>z</i>&#8242;-band\n          magnitudes down to <i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;=&#160;25.0, following a\n          procedure of network training and validation based on the subsample of objects with\n          spectroscopic redshifts. We splitted the spectroscopic sample into two subsets, using as\n          the training set 80% of the objects and as the validation set the remaining 20%. In order\n          to ensure a proper coverage of the parameter space we checked that the randomly extracted\n          populations had a spectroscopic distribution compatible with that of the whole\n          spectroscopic sample. Using subsamples of objects with spectroscopically measured\n          redshifts as training and validation sets makes the estimated\n            <i>z</i><sub>p</sub> insensitive to photometric systematic errors (due to zero\n          points or aperture corrections). In this sense this method is more effective than\n          classical methods based on Spectral Energy Distribution fitting (see Mercurio et al., in\n          prep., for further details on our <i>z</i><sub>p</sub> estimates). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a>\n              <p>Photometric <i>z</i><sub>p</sub> vs. spectroscopic <i>z</i> for\n                the sample of galaxies with <i>z</i> and\n                    18&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;23 in the cluster field.\n                Spectroscopic cluster members are indicated with black dots, galaxies selected\n                within the\n                  0.34&#160;&lt;&#160;<i>z</i><sub>p</sub>&#160;&lt;&#160;0.54\n                range <i>and </i>within the chosen\n                    <i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>I</i></sub>\n                vs.\n                    <i>m</i><sub><i>B</i></sub>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>V</i></sub>\n                color&#8722;color cut (see text) are indicated with red (grey) dots. Galaxies outside the\n                photometric and spectroscopic membership selection are indicated with blue\n                crosses.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>We must identify cluster members among the galaxies with <i>z</i><sub>p</sub>\n          and without spectroscopic redshifts to ensure that the number density profile we determine\n          is a fair representation of what we would have obtained using a complete sample of\n          spectroscopic members. We define the cluster membership by requiring\n            0.34&#160;&lt;&#160;<i>z</i><sub>p</sub>&#160;&lt;&#160;0.54\n          to ensure low contamination by foreground and background galaxies, and yet include most\n          cluster members (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F6\">6</a>). In the effort to limit\n          field contamination we also apply the following color&#8722;color cuts, chosen by inspecting the\n          location of the spectroscopic members in the color&#8722;color diagram:\n                <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq88.png\"></span><a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq89.png\"></span><a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq90.png\"></span>To\n          maximize the number of objects with spectroscopic redshifts we consider the magnitude\n          range 18&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;23. We then add to this\n          sample the spectroscopic members defined in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>. The combined sample of spectroscopic and photometric members contains 1597\n          galaxies, of which 54% are photometrically selected. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7</span></a>\n              <p>Projected galaxy number density profiles <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>)\n                (symbols with 1<i>&#963;</i> error bars) and best-fits (solid lines) for the\n                whole cluster population (black filled dots), for the population of passive cluster\n                galaxies (red open dots), and for the population of SF cluster galaxies (blue\n                stars). The best-fit models are pNFW for all and passive members, and the model of\n                  <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R107\">King (1962)</a> for the SF members. A constant\n                galaxy density background is added to all models. The vertical magenta dashed line\n                represents <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>The purity of the sample of photometrically-selected members can be estimated based on\n          the sample of galaxies with both spectroscopic and photometric redshifts. We define the\n          purity\n              <i>P</i>&#160;&#8801;&#160;<i>N</i><sub><i>pm</i>&#160;&#8745;&#160;<i>zm</i></sub>/<i>N</i><sub><i>pm</i>&#160;&#8745;&#160;<i>z</i></sub>,\n          where <i>N</i><sub><i>pm</i>&#160;&#8745;&#160;<i>z</i></sub> (respectively,\n            <i>N</i><sub><i>pm</i>&#160;&#8745;&#160;<i>zm</i></sub>) is the number of\n          galaxies with <i>z</i> (respectively, the number of spectroscopically confirmed\n          cluster members) which are selected as photometric members. We find\n          <i>P</i>&#160;=&#160;0.64. The color&#8722;color selection is useful to reduce the\n          contamination, especially by background objects. Had we not used the color&#8722;color\n          selection, the purity would have been lowered to 0.50. If we assume the spectroscopic\n          sample of members to have <i>P</i>&#160;=&#160;1, the combined sample of photometric and\n          spectroscopic members has <i>P</i>&#160;=&#160;0.82. </p>\n<p>We fit the number density profiles of this complete sample of (photometrically- and\n          spectroscopically-selected) cluster members, both for the full sample, and for the\n          subsamples of passive and SF galaxies (defined in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>), within the virial radius, using the same Maximum Likelihood technique\n          already used for the spectroscopic sample. As before we consider either a pNFW or a King\n          model, but this time we add an additional constant background density parameter in both\n          models. The background density parameter is needed because we expect that the photometric\n          membership selection is contaminated by noncluster members. From the estimate of the\n          purity of the sample, we expect 18% of the selected members to be spurious, and this\n          corresponds to 8 background galaxies Mpc<sup>-2</sup> in our sample of\n          photometrically-selected members, 3/4 of which are SF galaxies. This value is very close\n          to the density of photometrically-selected members in the external cluster regions,\n            4&#160;&lt;&#160;<i>R</i>&#160;&lt;&#160;5 Mpc, where\n          the field contamination of this sample is likely to be dominant. </p>\n<p>Once the background galaxy density parameter is fixed, the only remaining free parameter\n          in the fit is the scale radius. The results of our fits are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a> and displayed in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F7\">7</a>. The pNFW model provides a better fit than the King model for the samples of\n          all and passive members, while the King model is preferable to the pNFW model for the\n          sample of SF galaxies. All fits are acceptable within the 69% confidence level, with\n          reduced <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> of 1.1, 1.2, and 0.8, for the populations of all,\n          passive, and SF galaxies, respectively. These results are very similar to those obtained\n          using the spectroscopically-selected cluster members. </p>\n<p>In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S6\">3.1</a> we will use the\n            <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>) best-fits of the whole cluster population within\n          the MAMPOSSt method. We will consider both results listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a> to check how much our dynamical results depend on the best-fit\n          solution for the <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>) scale radius. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>3. The mass profile</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>3.1. The MAMPOSSt method</h3>\n<p>The MAMPOSSt method (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">Mamon et al. 2013</a>) aims to\n          determine the mass and velocity anisotropy profiles of a cluster in parametrized form, by\n          performing a maximum likelihood fit of the distribution of galaxies in projected phase\n          space. MAMPOSSt does not postulate a shape for the distribution function in terms of\n          energy and angular momentum, and does not suppose Gaussian line-of-sight velocity\n          distributions, but assumes a shape for the 3D velocity distribution (taken to be Gaussian\n          in our analysis). This method has been extensively tested using cluster-mass halos\n          extracted from cosmological simulations. It assumes dynamical equilibrium, hence it should\n          not be applied to data much beyond the virial radius. Following the indications of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">Mamon et al. (2013)</a> we only consider data within\n            <i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>. We also exclude the very inner\n          region, within 0.05 Mpc, since it is dominated by the internal dynamics of the BCG, rather\n          than by the overall cluster (see, e.g., <a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R34\">Biviano &amp;\n            Salucci 2006</a>). Our MAMPOSSt analysis is therefore based on the sample of 330\n          cluster members with\n              0.05&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>. Of\n          these, 250 are passive galaxies (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>). </p>\n<p>The MAMPOSSt method requires parametrized models for the number density, mass, and\n          velocity anisotropy profiles &#8211; <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>),\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>), <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>), but\n          there is no limitation in the possible choice of these models. Since our spectroscopic\n          data-set might suffer from (mild) radial-dependent incompleteness, we prefer not to let\n          MAMPOSSt fit <i>&#957;</i>(<i>r</i>) directly; rather, we use the\n          de-projected <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>) best-fit models obtained in Sect.\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S4\">2.2</a> (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a>). We refer to the scale radius of the number density profile as\n            <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> in the following. </p>\n<p>As for <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>), we consider the following models:</p>\n<p>\n          <ul style=\"list-style-type: none;\">\n            <li>\n              1. \n              <p class=\"ligne\"> the NFW model, <a name=\"FD6\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq103.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(3)</span></span></p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              2. \n              <p class=\"ligne\"> the Hernquist model (<a name=\"InR93\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R93\">Hernquist 1990</a>),\n                  <a name=\"FD7\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq104.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(4)</span></span>where\n                  <i>r</i><sub>H</sub>&#160;=&#160;2&#160;<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>, </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              3. \n              <p class=\"ligne\"> the Einasto model (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R65\">Einasto 1965</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R133\">Mamon et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR195\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R195\">Tamm et al. 2012</a>),\n                      <a name=\"\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq106.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(5)</span></span>where\n                  <i>P</i>(<i>a,x</i>)&#160;=&#160;<i>&#947;</i>(<i>a,x</i>)/&#915;(<i>a</i>)\n                is the regularized incomplete gamma function, and where we fix\n                <i>m</i>&#160;=&#160;5, a typical value for cluster-size halos extracted from\n                cosmological numerical simulations (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R133\">Mamon et al.\n                  2010</a>), </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              4. \n              <p class=\"ligne\"> the Burkert model (<a name=\"InR43\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R43\">Burkert 1995</a>),\n                  <a name=\"FD9\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq109.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(6)</span></span>where\n                  <i>r</i><sub>B</sub>&#160;&#8771;&#160;2/3&#160;<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>,\n              </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              5. \n              <p class=\"ligne\"> the Softened Isothermal Sphere (SIS model, hereafter; see e.g. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R80\">Geller et al. 1999</a>) <a name=\"FD10\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq111.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(7)</span></span>where\n                  <i>r</i><sub>I</sub> is the core radius. </p>\n            </li>\n          </ul>\n        </p>\n<p>The NFW and Hernquist mass density profiles are characterized by central logarithmic\n          slopes <i>&#947;</i>&#160;=&#160;&#160;&#8722;1, while the Burkert and SIS mass density profiles have a\n          central core, <i>&#947;</i>&#160;=&#160;0. Somewhat in between these two extremes, the Einasto\n          profile has not a fixed central slope but one that asymptotically approaches zero near the\n          center,\n            <i>&#947;</i>&#160;=&#160;&#160;&#8722;2&#160;(<i>r</i>/<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>)<sup>1/<i>m</i></sup>.\n          The asymptotic slopes of the NFW, Hernquist, Burkert, and SIS mass density profiles are\n            <i>&#947;</i>&#160;=&#160;&#160;&#8722;3,&#160;&#8722;4,&#160;&#8722;3,\n          and &#8722;2, respectively. The NFW and the Einasto models have been shown to successfully\n          describe the mass density profiles of observed clusters (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S1\">1</a>). The Hernquist model is well studied (e.g. <a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R10\">Baes &amp; Dejonghe 2002</a>) and it has been shown to provide a good\n          fit to the mass profile of galaxy clusters (<a name=\"InR172\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R172\">Rines et al.\n            2000</a>, <a name=\"InR173\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R173\">2001</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R174\">2003</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R171\">Rines &amp; Diaferio\n            2006</a>). This is also true of the Burkert model (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R103\">Katgert et al. 2004</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R34\">Biviano &amp; Salucci\n            2006</a>), but not of the SIS model (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R174\">Rines et al.\n            2003</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R103\">Katgert et al. 2004</a>). </p>\n<p>As for <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>), we consider the following models:</p>\n<p>\n          <ul style=\"list-style-type: none;\">\n            <li>\n              1. \n              <p class=\"ligne\"> &#8220;C&#8221;: Constant anisotropy with radius,\n                    <i>&#946;</i>&#160;=&#160;<i>&#946;</i><sub><i>C</i></sub>; </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              2. \n              <p class=\"ligne\"> &#8220;T&#8221;: from <a name=\"InR201\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R201\">Tiret et al. (2007)</a>,\n                  <a name=\"FD11\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq119.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(8)</span></span>isotropic at the\n                center, with anisotropy radius identical to <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>,\n                characterized by the anisotropy value at large radii,\n                <i>&#946;</i><sub>&#8734;</sub>; </p>\n            </li>\n            <li>\n              3. \n              <p class=\"ligne\"> &#8220;O&#8221;: anisotropy of opposite sign at the center and at large radii, <a name=\"FD12\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq121.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(9)</span></span></p>\n            </li>\n          </ul>The\n          C model is the simplest, and has been frequently used in previous studies (e.g. <a name=\"InR139\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R139\">Merritt 1987</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R205\">van der\n            Marel et al. 2000</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R122\">&#321;okas &amp; Mamon\n            2003</a>). The T model has been shown by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R133\">Mamon et\n            al. (2010</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R134\">2013)</a> to provide a good fit to\n          the velocity anisotropy profiles of cosmological cluster-mass halos. Here we introduce the\n          O model to account for the possibility of deviation from the general behavior observed in\n          numerically simulated halos &#8211; the O model allows for nonisotropic orbits near the cluster\n          center while the T model does not. Isotropic orbits are allowed in all three models. Note\n          that the <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> parameter common to the T and O models is the\n          same parameter that enters the NFW and Einasto <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>)\n          models, and is related to the scale parameters of the Hernquist and Burkert\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) models. For the SIS model\n            <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> cannot be uniquely defined, hence we can only consider\n          the C <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model, and not the T and O models. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2</span></a>\n              <p>Results of the MAMPOSSt analysis.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a>\n              <p><i>Top panel</i>: mass profiles as obtained from the MAMPOSSt and Caustic\n                analyses. The MAMPOSSt result is that obtained using the NFW model and the O\n                  <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model, and is represented by a black curve\n                within a grey shaded area (1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region). The Caustic\n                result is represented by green dash-dotted curves (central value within\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region). The black dot and green square represent\n                the locations of the\n                  [<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>M</i><sub>200</sub>]\n                values for the MAMPOSSt and Caustic <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>).\n                  <i>Bottom panel</i>: fractional difference between different mass\n                profiles and the MAMPOSSt best-fit to the NFW <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>)\n                with O <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model (displayed in the top panel).\n                The MAMPOSSt best-fit O <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) Hernquist, Einasto,\n                and Burkert models are represented by the blue long-dashed, gold triple-dot-dashed,\n                and red short-dashed curves, respectively. The MAMPOSSt best-fit C\n                  <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) SIS model is represented by the magenta\n                dotted curve. The Caustic <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence levels are represented by the green dash-dotted\n                curves. The solid line marks the zero and the grey shaded area the\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region of the NFW model fit. Symbols represent the\n                location of the\n                  [<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>M</i><sub>200</sub>/<i>M</i><sub><i>NFW</i></sub>(<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>)&#160;&#8722;&#160;1]\n                values for the different mass profiles, NFW (filled black dot), Hernquist (blue X),\n                Einasto (gold star), Burkert (red triangle), SIS (magenta inverted triangle),\n                Caustic (green square). The NFW and Burkert values are barely visible in the plot,\n                because they are virtually indistinguishable from the Einasto and Hernquist values.\n                All MAMPOSSt results displayed here are for the\n                    <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>&#160;=&#160;0.63 Mpc value (see Table\n                  <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">2</a>).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9</span></a>\n              <p>Results of the MAMPOSSt analysis using the NFW and O models for\n                  <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>),\n                respectively. The vertical lines and dots indicate the best-fit solutions. The\n                likelihood distributions on each parameter are obtained by marginalizing vs. the\n                other two parameters. Gray-shading in the likelihood distribution plots indicate the\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence regions. The red, gray-shaded contours are\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence levels on the two labeled parameters, obtained by\n                marginalizing vs. the third parameter. Note that we show results for\n                  <i>&#963;</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>/<i>&#963;</i><sub><i>&#952;</i></sub>\n                rather than for <i>&#946;</i> (see Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#FD1\">1</a>)).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In total, we run MAMPOSSt with 3 free parameters, i.e. the virial radius\n            <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>, the scale radius of the total mass distribution\n            <i>r</i><sub><i>&#961;</i></sub> (equal to\n            <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>,<i>r</i><sub>H</sub>,<i>r</i><sub>B</sub>\n          or <i>r</i><sub>I</sub>, depending on the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>)\n          model), and the anisotropy parameter, <i>&#946;</i><sub><i>C</i></sub> or\n            <i>&#946;</i><sub>&#8734;</sub>. Note that we do <i>not </i>assume that light\n          traces mass, i.e. we allow the scale radius of the total mass distribution to be different\n          from that of the galaxy distribution,\n            <i>r</i><sub><i>&#961;</i></sub>&#160;&#8800;&#160;<i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>.\n          The results of the MAMPOSSt analysis are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">2</a>. The best-fits are obtained using the NEWUOA software for unconstrained\n          optimization (<a name=\"InR165\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R165\">Powell 2006</a>). The errors on each of\n          the parameters listed in the table are obtained by a marginalization procedure, i.e. by\n          integrating the probabilities\n            <i>p</i>(<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>r</i><sub><i>&#961;</i></sub><i>,&#946;</i>)\n          provided by MAMPOSSt, over the remaining two free parameters. </p>\n<p>In Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">2</a> we list two sets of results, one for\n          each of the best-fit values of <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> found in\n          Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S4\">2.2</a>. The results are very similar in the two\n          cases. On average, the values of\n            <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>r</i><sub><i>&#961;</i></sub>,\n          and <i>&#946;</i> or <i>&#946;</i><sub>&#8734;</sub> change by 2, 5, and 2 %,\n          respectively. These variations are much smaller than the statistical errors on the\n          parameters, therefore we only consider the set of results obtained for\n              <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>&#160;=&#160;0.63 Mpc, in the following (this is\n          the value obtained for the complete sample of spectroscopic + photometric cluster members,\n          see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S4\">2.2</a>). </p>\n<p>Using the likelihood-ratio test (<a name=\"InR142\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R142\">Meyer 1975</a>) we\n          find that all models are statistically acceptable (likelihood ratios are listed in the\n          last column of Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">2</a>). This is also visible from\n          Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F8\">8</a> where we display the five\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) corresponding to the best-fit NFW, Hernquist,\n          Einasto, and Burkert models with O <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>), and to the\n          best-fit SIS model with <i>C</i><i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>). The SIS\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) is in some tension with the others due to the\n          fact that it is essentially a single power-law, as the value of its core radius\n            <i>r</i><sub>I</sub> is constrained by the MAMPOSSt analysis to be very small\n          (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">2</a>). </p>\n<p>The different models give best-fit values of <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> in\n          agreement within their 1<i>&#963;</i> errors. The rms of all\n            <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> values is 0.04, smaller than the error on any\n          individual <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> value. This is also true of the\n            <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> parameter (we use the appropriate scaling factors to\n          convert <i>r</i><sub>H</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>B</sub> to\n            <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>), for which the rms is 0.08, and of the anisotropy\n          parameter for which the rms is 0.06. </p>\n<p>Since the uncertainties on the values of the parameters are dominated by statistical\n          errors, and not by the systematics induced by the model choice, for simplicity in the rest\n          of this paper we only consider the MAMPOSSt results obtained for one of the considered\n          models. We choose the NFW model for <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>), for the sake\n          of comparing our results to those of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>, and also\n          because it provides slightly higher likelihoods than the Hernquist, Burkert, and SIS mass\n          models (for fixed <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model) and comparable likelihoods\n          to those of the Einasto model. As for the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model, we\n          choose the O model, since it is the one that gives the smallest errors on the\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) parameters, in the sense of maximizing the figure\n          of merit\n            FoM&#8201;&#160;&#160;&#8801;&#160;(<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>)/(<i>&#948;</i><i>r</i><sub>200</sub>&#160;<i>&#948;</i><i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>),\n          where <i>&#948;</i><i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and\n            <i>&#948;</i><i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> are the (symmetrized) errors on,\n          respectively, <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>. In\n          Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F9\">9</a> we display the results of the MAMPOSSt\n          analysis for the NFW+O models. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S9\">4</a> we will\n          show how the best-fit <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) models for the NFW mass model\n          compare with our nonparametric <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) determination from\n          the Jeans inversion (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F15\">15</a>). </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>3.2. The Caustic method</h3>\n<p>The Caustic method (<a name=\"InR59\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R59\">Diaferio &amp; Geller\n          1997</a>; <a name=\"InR58\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R58\">Diaferio 1999</a>) is based on the\n          identification of density discontinuities in the\n            <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub> space. This method does not require\n          the assumption of dynamical equilibrium outside the virial region, hence it makes use of\n          all galaxies, not only of member galaxies, and can provide\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) also at\n            <i>r</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>. Moreover\n          the method does not require to assume a model for <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>).\n          This comes at the price of some simplifying assumptions that can induce systematic errors,\n          as we see below. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3</span></a>\n              <p>Best-fit dynamical parameters for the NFW <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>)\n                model.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10</span></a>\n              <p>Caustics in the <i>R,</i><i>v</i><sub>rf</sub> space; the\n                thick-line caustic is the one identified following the prescription of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R58\">Diaferio (1999)</a>. Filled dots identify members\n                selected using the P+G method; the vertical line indicates the location of\n                  <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F11\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11</span></a>\n              <p>The &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub> function obtained by adopting the best-fit\n                  <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) NFW model with an O\n                  <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model, using MAMPOSSt (solid black curve)\n                within 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region (hatched gray region). The two\n                horizontal dashed lines indicate two commonly adopted constant values of\n                    &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub> in the literature.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F10\">10</a> we show the projected phase-space\n          distribution of all galaxies and galaxy iso-number density contours, computed using\n          Gaussian adaptive kernels with an initial &#8220;optimal&#8221; kernel size (as defined in <a name=\"InR189\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R189\">Silverman 1986</a>). Before estimating the density\n          contours, rest-frame velocities and clustercentric distances are scaled in such a way as\n          to have the same dispersion for the scaled radii and scaled velocities. The data-set is\n          mirrored across the <i>R</i>&#160;=&#160;0 axis before the density contours are estimated,\n          to avoid edge-effects problems. To choose the density threshold that defines the contour\n          (the &#8220;caustic&#8221;) to use, we follow the prescriptions of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R58\">Diaferio (1999)</a>, which depend on an estimate of the velocity dispersion of\n          cluster members. We use the P+G cluster membership definition (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>), for consistency with the rest of our dynamical analyses in this\n          paper. </p>\n<p>The velocity amplitude of the chosen caustic is related to\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) via a function of both the gravitational\n          potential and <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>), called\n            &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>. For simplicity most studies (with the notable exception\n          of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R29\">Biviano &amp; Girardi 2003</a>) have so far used\n          constant &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>(<i>r</i>), following the initial\n          suggestion of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R59\">Diaferio &amp; Geller (1997)</a> and\n            <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R58\">Diaferio (1999)</a>. With the most recent\n          implementation of the caustic algorithm by <a name=\"InR187\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R187\">Serra et al.\n            (2011)</a>, the value of &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>&#160;=&#160;0.7 was adopted. The value\n              &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>&#160;=&#160;0.5 preferred by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R59\">Diaferio &amp; Geller (1997)</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R58\">Diaferio\n            (1999)</a>, and <a name=\"InR81\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R81\">Geller et al. (2013)</a> was\n          appropriate for an earlier implementation of the algorithm that however tended to\n          overestimate the escape velocity by 15&#8211;20% on average. </p>\n<p>The unknown value of &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub> is a major systematic uncertainty in\n          this method. The correct value of &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub> to use might be different\n          for different membership definitions, as suggested by the analysis of numerically\n          simulated halos of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R187\">Serra et al. (2011)</a>. For\n          consistency we use for the Caustic method the same membership definition used for the\n          MAMPOSSt analysis (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S6\">3.1</a>). We can therefore\n          take advantage of our MAMPOSSt-based determinations of\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) to\n          determine &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub> for the Caustic method. </p>\n<p>We adopt the best-fit NFW <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) + O\n            <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">2</a>) and obtain the &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>(<i>r</i>) shown in\n          Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F11\">11</a>. The large uncertainty associated to the\n            <i>&#946;</i><sub>&#8734;</sub> parameter of the O model propagates into a large\n          uncertainty on &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>. Within the uncertainties\n              &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>(<i>r</i>) is consistent with the value of 0.7\n          but only at radii <i>r</i>&#160;&gt;&#160;0.5 Mpc. It is instead\n          inconsistent with the value of 0.5 at most radii. Over most of the radial range,\n              &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>(<i>r</i>) is intermediate between these two\n          commonly adopted constant values, but not near the center, where it is smaller.\n              Constant-&#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub> Caustic determinations of\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) are known to suffer from an overestimate at small\n          radii (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R187\">Serra et al. 2011</a>); the radial dependence\n          of our adopted &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>(<i>r</i>) is likely to correct for\n          this bias. </p>\n<p>The uncertainties in the Caustic <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) estimate are\n          derived following the prescriptions of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R58\">Diaferio\n            (1999)</a>. According to <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R187\">Serra et al. (2011)</a>\n          these prescriptions lead to estimate 50% confidence levels; we therefore multiply them by\n          1.4 to have ~1<i>&#963;</i> confidence levels. </p>\n<p>The Caustic <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) within its 1<i>&#963;</i>\n          confidence region is shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F8\">8</a>. It is\n          consistent with the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) obtained via the MAMPOSSt\n          method. This consistency is at least partly enforced by the fact that we calibrated\n              &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub>(<i>r</i>) using the results we obtained with\n          MAMPOSSt. </p>\n<p>We obtain the mass density profile <i>&#961;</i>(<i>r</i>) from numerical\n          differentiation of the Caustic <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>), and then fit the\n          NFW model, limiting the fit to radii below twice\n              <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> (we can extend the fit beyond\n            <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> because the Caustic method is not\n          based on the assumption of dynamical equilibrium). The best-fit is obtained from a\n            <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup>-minimization procedure. Uncertainties in the best-fit\n          value are obtained using the <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> distribution, by setting the\n          effective number of independent data to the ratio between the used radial range in the fit\n          and the adaptive-kernel radial scale used to determine the caustic itself. The NFW model\n          provides a good fit to the Caustic <i>&#961;</i>(<i>r</i>) over the full\n          radial range considered (reduced <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup>&#160;=&#160;0.4). </p>\n<p>The best-fit <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> values\n          of the NFW model fitted to the Caustic-derived mass density profile, and their\n          marginalized 1<i>&#963;</i> errors, are listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T3\">3</a>. For comparison, we also list in the same Table the adopted results of\n          the MAMPOSSt analysis (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S6\">3.1</a>). The MAMPOSSt and\n          Caustic values of <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> are\n          consistent within their error bars. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>3.3. Combining different mass profile determinations</h3>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F12\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig12_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 12</span></a>\n              <p>Best-fit solutions and 1<i>&#963;</i> contours in the\n                  <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>-<i>c</i><sub>200</sub> space for the\n                NFW <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) model (see also Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T3\">3</a>). Lensing analysis of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>: small magenta-filled region (with white border) and white\n                filled dot. MAMPOSSt analysis: black vertically-elongated contour and filled square.\n                Caustic analysis: green inclined contour and green diamond. Joint MAMPOSSt + Caustic\n                constraints: gray-filled region and gray dot with yellow borders. Best-fit value and\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> error bars from the\n                  <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>+<i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>\n                analysis: big red cross. The solid (resp. dashed) blue line and shaded cyan region\n                represent the theoretical <i>cMr</i> of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R23\">Bhattacharya et al. (2013)</a> for relaxed (resp. all) halos and its\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> scatter. The dash-dotted blue line represents the theoretical\n                  <i>cMr</i> of <a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R53\">De Boni et al.\n                  (2013)</a> for relaxed halos.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F13\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig13_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 13</span></a>\n              <p><i>Top panel</i>: the projected mass profile\n                  <i>M</i><sub>p</sub>(<i>R</i>) from the joint MAMPOSSt+Caustic\n                pNFW solution (solid yellow line) within 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region\n                (hatched gray region), and from the lensing analysis of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> (dashed white line: strong lensing analysis; dash-dotted\n                line: weak lensing analysis, after subtraction of the contribution of the\n                large-scale structure along the line-of-sight) within 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence\n                region (hatched magenta regions). The black triple-dots-dashed line is the pNFW mass\n                profile from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>&#8217;s analysis of Chandra data.\n                The vertical dashed line indicates the location of\n                    <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> in both panels.\n                  <i>Bottom panel</i>: the ratio between the kinematic and lensing\n                determinations of <i>M</i><sub>p</sub>(<i>R</i>). The white\n                dashed and dash-dotted (resp. solid yellow) line represents the ratio obtained using\n                the non parametric determination (resp. the pNFW parametrization) of the lensing\n                  <i>M</i><sub>p</sub>(<i>R</i>). The pink hatched region\n                represents the confidence region of this ratio for the non parametric\n                  <i>M</i><sub>p</sub>(<i>R</i>) lensing solution. The\n                horizontal black dotted line indicates the value of unity.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F14\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 14</span></a>\n              <p>The solid (white and green) curve and hatched (magenta and green) region represent\n                our fiducial <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) within 1<i>&#963;</i>\n                confidence levels. This corresponds to the NFW best-fit to the lensing mass profile\n                of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> (white curve within magenta region)\n                out to <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> (indicated by a vertical\n                dashed line), and to the Caustic non parametric mass profile (green curve within\n                light green region) beyond that radius. The dashed black curve represents the NFW\n                best-fit solution obtained by the combined MAMPOSSt+Caustic analysis.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S6\">3.1</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S7\">3.2</a> we have found that the NFW model is the best description of\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) among the three we have considered. This is a\n          particularly welcome result because also <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> found\n          that the NFW model is a good description to the cluster\n            <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) obtained by a gravitational lensing analysis.
