               \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                </ol>\n    </div>\n\n  <h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S16\"></a>Online material</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>Appendix A: The effects of different cluster membership definitions</h3>\n<a name=\"SD1\"></a><p>The determinations of <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n              <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) described in Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S5\">3</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S9\">4</a> are based, at least in\n            part, on the sample of cluster members defined by the P+G procedure (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>). Here we examine how a different cluster\n            membership definition affects our results. For this, we here consider the membership\n            definition obtained with the Clean method instead of the P+G method. The two methods use\n            very different approaches for the identification of cluster members, as described in\n            Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S3\">2.1</a>. </p>\n<p>In Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T4\">A.1</a> we list the fractional differences\n            and associated 1<i>&#963;</i> uncertainties of the\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> and\n              <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> determinations obtained by using the\n            two samples of cluster members identified with the P+G and the Clean methods. The\n            effects of changing the method of membership selection are marginal, as all changes are\n            within 1<i>&#963;</i>. </p>\n<p>\n            <a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table A.1</span></a>\n                <p>Effects of changing the member selection method (Clean vs. P+G).</p>\n              </div></div>\n          </p>\n<p>The <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> estimates are all slightly increased when adopting\n            the Clean method instead of the P+G method, and this happens because of the 8 galaxies\n            with high absolute values of <i>v</i><sub>rf</sub> near the cluster center\n            selected as members by the Clean method but not by the P+G method (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F2\">2</a>). Since 7 of these 8 galaxies are passive, the\n            effects of the different membership selection are stronger on the quantities derived\n            using only passive galaxies. </p>\n<p>The inclusion of these 8 galaxies in the sample of cluster members causes a higher\n            velocity dispersion estimate near the center, and therefore a steeper\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profile. To accommodate for the steeper\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profile near the center, the MAMPOSSt analysis forces\n            more concentrated mass profiles, with 20&#8211;25% smaller <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>\n            estimates. However, given the large uncertainties on the <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>\n            estimates these changes are far from being significant. The Caustic\n              <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) estimate is less affected, because i) it is\n            only partially based on the membership selection within the virial radius, and ii) it\n            uses all galaxies (and not only members) also beyond the virial radius. </p>\n<p>The <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> estimates depend very little on\n            which membership selection is chosen, because i) they are based not only on the sample\n            of spectroscopic members but also on the sample of\n            <i>z</i><sub>p</sub>-selected members; and ii) the inclusion of the 8\n            additional members near the center has a smaller impact on\n              <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>) than it has on\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>(<i>R</i>). </p>\n<p>Given the marginal changes in the MAMPOSSt and Caustic estimates of\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>, using the\n            Clean-based membership determination instead of the P+G-based one, we still find\n            consistency between the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) obtained via the MAMPOSSt\n            and Caustic method and that of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>. As a\n            consequence, we would still adopt the <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> within\n                <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> and the Caustic\n              <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) at larger radii, and the resulting\n              <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) would be almost identical to the one we adopted\n            using the P+G membership determination (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S8\">3.3</a>). </p>\n<p>\n            \n            <a name=\"F19\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F19.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig19_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F19.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. A.1</span></a>\n                <p>Difference of the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) determined using the\n                  Clean and P+G samples of members. The solid (white), dashed (red), and dash-dotted\n                  (cyan) curves are for all, passive, and SF galaxies, respectively.\n                    1<i>&#963;</i> intervals on the differences are shown as shaded regions,\n                  with 45, 0, and 90 degrees orientation of the (gray, orange, blue) shading for\n                  all, passive, and SF galaxies, respectively. </p>\n              </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n          </p>\n<p>The <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) profiles resulting from the inversion of the\n            Jeans equation are marginally affected mostly because of the steepening of the\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> profile. Given that the adopted\n              <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) is almost unchanged with respect to the case of\n            P+G membership selection, the steepening of\n              <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>(<i>R</i>) near the center must be\n            compensated by an increased radial anisotropy. This concerns mostly the passive\n            galaxies. The differences between the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) obtained\n            using the Clean-based sample of members and those obtained using the P+G-based sample of\n            members are consistent with zero within 1<i>&#963;</i> for all cluster populations\n            and at all radii (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F19\">A.1</a>). </p>\n<p>We conclude that our results do not change significantly if we use the Clean instead of\n            the P+G method for membership selection. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S18\"></a>Appendix B: Comparison with other cluster mass estimates from the literature</h3>\n<a name=\"SD2\"></a><p>We here compare our results to those obtained by <a name=\"InR76\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R76\">Fo&#235;x\n              et al. (2012)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a>.\n            In both cases their data were of insufficiently quality to constrain both\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>, so we only\n            compare the <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> values. </p>\n<p>The weak lensing <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> estimate of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R76\">Fo&#235;x et al. (2012)</a>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq302.png\"></span>\n            Mpc, is in good agreement with our estimate. </p>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a> have estimated the cluster\n            mass in three ways; i) by strong lensing; ii) by an hydrostatic equilibrium analysis of\n            the X-ray emitting intra-cluster medium; and iii) by the virial theorem. Their strong\n            lensing mass estimate, 1.12&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>14</sup><i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> within 0.12\n            Mpc from the cluster center, is in agreement with our determinations. By applying a\n            scaling relation to the cluster X-ray temperature <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a> obtain an approximate value of\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>, 2.3&#160;&#160;&#177;&#160;&#160;0.1 Mpc, in disagreement with our\n            estimate. They then estimate the cluster mass within this radius using an isothermal\n              <i>&#946;</i> model profile,\n              1.7&#160;&#177;&#160;1&#160;&#215;&#160;10<sup>15</sup>&#160;&#160;<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>. This\n              <i>M</i><sub>200</sub> estimate corresponds to a\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> estimate of 2.1 Mpc, different from their initial\n            estimate, but still above our best estimate. Had they iterated their Eq. (5) they would\n            have obtained a concordant pair of\n              <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>M</i><sub>200</sub>\n            estimates with a final value of <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> of 2.03 Mpc, closer to\n            our best estimate. </p>\n<p>The virial theorem mass estimate of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al.\n              (2009)</a> is instead grossly discrepant with any other estimate discussed so far.\n            This appears to be due to a combination of causes. </p>\n<p>First, their membership selection is too simplistic since it does not take into account\n            the radial position of galaxies. As a consequence, they obtain a much larger velocity\n            dispersion estimate than we do, 1581 km s<sup>-1</sup> (compare to the values in Table\n              <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">1</a>). Their large estimate is also due to the\n            fact that <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> is decreasing with <i>R</i> (see\n            Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F3\">3</a>) and their spectroscopic sample does not\n            reach <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>. Other causes that lead <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R64\">Ebeling et al. (2009)</a> to overestimate the cluster\n            mass using the virial theorem are the neglect of the surface-pressure term (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R199\">The &amp; White 1986</a>), and the use of a\n            spatially incomplete sample in the estimate of the projected harmonic mean radius (see\n              <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R37\">Biviano et al. 2006</a>). </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"tabs\"></a>All Tables</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a>\n              <p>Values of the line-of-sight velocity dispersions, <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>,\n                and of the best-fit parameters of the galaxy number density profiles,\n                  <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>).</p>\n            <div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T1\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2</span></a>\n              <p>Results of the MAMPOSSt analysis.</p>\n            <div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a             model.</p>\n            <div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T3\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table A.1</span></a>\n                <p>Effects of changing the member selection method (Clean vs. P+G).</p>\n              <div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T4\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a This is the ratio of two adaptive-kernel number\n                density maps, one for all the objects with <i>z</i>, and the other for all\n                the photometric objects, both within the magnitude range\n                    18&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>m</i><sub><i>R</i></sub>&#160;&#8804;&#160;23. The best-fit models are pNFW for all and passive members, and the model of\n                  <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R107\">King (1962)</a> for the SF members. A constant\n                galaxy density background is added to all models. The vertical magenta dashed line\n                represents <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F7\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a>\n              <p><i>Top panel</i>: mass profiles as obtained from the MAMPOSSt and Caustic\n                analyses. The MAMPOSSt result is that obtained using the NFW model and the O\n                  <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model, and is represented by a black curve\n                within a grey shaded area (1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region). The Caustic\n                result is represented by green dash-dotted curves (central value within\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region). The black dot and green square represent\n                the locations of the\n                  [<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>M</i><sub>200</sub>]\n                values for the MAMPOSSt and Caustic <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>).\n                  <i>Bottom panel</i>: fractional difference between different mass\n                profiles and the MAMPOSSt best-fit to the NFW <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>)\n                with O <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model (displayed in the top panel).\n                The MAMPOSSt best-fit O <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) Hernquist, Einasto,\n                and Burkert models are represented by the blue long-dashed, gold triple-dot-dashed,\n                and red short-dashed curves, respectively. The MAMPOSSt best-fit C\n                  <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) SIS model is represented by the magenta\n                dotted curve. The Caustic <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence levels are represented by the green dash-dotted\n                curves. The solid line marks the zero and the grey shaded area the\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region of the NFW model fit. Symbols represent the\n                location of the\n                  [<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>M</i><sub>200</sub>/<i>M</i><sub><i>NFW</i></sub>(<i>r</i><sub>200</sub>)&#160;&#8722;&#160;1]\n                values for the different mass profiles, NFW (filled black dot), Hernquist (blue X),\n                Einasto (gold star), Burkert (red triangle), SIS (magenta inverted triangle),\n                Caustic (green square). The NFW and Burkert values are barely visible in the plot,\n                because they are virtually indistinguishable from the Einasto and Hernquist values.\n                All MAMPOSSt results displayed here are for the\n                    <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>&#160;=&#160;0.63 Mpc value (see Table\n                  <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T2\">2</a>).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F8\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9</span></a>\n              <p>Results of the MAMPOSSt analysis using the NFW and O models for\n                  <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) and <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>),\n                respectively. The vertical lines and dots indicate the best-fit solutions. The\n                likelihood distributions on each parameter are obtained by marginalizing vs. the\n                other two parameters. Gray-shading in the likelihood distribution plots indicate the\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence regions. The red, gray-shaded contours are\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> confidence levels on the two labeled parameters, obtained by\n                marginalizing vs. the third parameter. Note that we show results for\n                  <i>&#963;</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>/<i>&#963;</i><sub><i>&#952;</i></sub>\n                rather than for <i>&#946;</i> (see Eq. Filled dots identify members\n                selected using the P+G method; the vertical line indicates the location of\n                  <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub>.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F10\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11</span></a>\n              <p>The &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub> function obtained by adopting the best-fit\n                  <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) NFW model with an O\n                  <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) model, using MAMPOSSt (solid black curve)\n                within 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region (hatched gray region). The two\n                horizontal dashed lines indicate two commonly adopted constant values of\n                    &#8497;<sub><i>&#946;</i></sub> in the literature.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F11\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig12_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 12</span></a>\n              <p>Best-fit solutions and 1<i>&#963;</i> contours in the\n                  <i>M</i><sub>200</sub>-<i>c</i><sub>200</sub> space for the\n                NFW <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) model (see also Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#T3\">3</a>). Lensing analysis of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>: small magenta-filled region (with white border) and white\n                filled dot. MAMPOSSt analysis: black vertically-elongated contour and filled square.\n                Caustic analysis: green inclined contour and green diamond. Joint MAMPOSSt + Caustic\n                constraints: gray-filled region and gray dot with yellow borders. Best-fit value and\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> error bars from the\n                  <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>+<i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>\n                analysis: big red cross. The solid (resp. dashed) blue line and shaded cyan region\n                represent the theoretical <i>cMr</i> of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R23\">Bhattacharya et al. (2013)</a> for relaxed (resp. all) halos and its\n                  1<i>&#963;</i> scatter. The dash-dotted blue line represents the theoretical\n                  <i>cMr</i> of <a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R53\">De Boni et al.\n                  (2013)</a> for relaxed halos.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F12\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig13_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 13</span></a>\n              <p><i>Top panel</i>: the projected mass profile\n                  <i>M</i><sub>p</sub>(<i>R</i>) from the joint MAMPOSSt+Caustic\n                pNFW solution (solid yellow line) within 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region\n                (hatched gray region), and from the lensing analysis of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> (dashed white line: strong lensing analysis; dash-dotted\n                line: weak lensing analysis, after subtraction of the contribution of the\n                large-scale structure along the line-of-sight) within 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence\n                region (hatched magenta regions). The black triple-dots-dashed line is the pNFW mass\n                profile from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>&#8217;s analysis of Chandra data.\n                The vertical dashed line indicates the location of\n                    <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> in both panels.\n                  <i>Bottom panel</i>: the ratio between the kinematic and lensing\n                determinations of <i>M</i><sub>p</sub>(<i>R</i>). The white\n                dashed and dash-dotted (resp. solid yellow) line represents the ratio obtained using\n                the non parametric determination (resp. the pNFW parametrization) of the lensing\n                  <i>M</i><sub>p</sub>(<i>R</i>). The pink hatched region\n                represents the confidence region of this ratio for the non parametric\n                  <i>M</i><sub>p</sub>(<i>R</i>) lensing solution. The\n                horizontal black dotted line indicates the value of unity.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F13\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 14</span></a>\n              <p>The solid (white and green) curve and hatched (magenta and green) region represent\n                our fiducial <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) within 1<i>&#963;</i>\n                confidence levels. This corresponds to the NFW best-fit to the lensing mass profile\n                of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a> (white curve within magenta region)\n                out to <i>r</i><sub>200,U</sub> (indicated by a vertical\n                dashed line), and to the Caustic non parametric mass profile (green curve within\n                light green region) beyond that radius. The dashed black curve represents the NFW\n                best-fit solution obtained by the combined MAMPOSSt+Caustic analysis.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F14\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig15_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 15</span></a>\n            <p>Velocity-anisotropy profile, <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>), of different\n              cluster galaxy populations. <i>Top panel</i>: all cluster members. The solid\n              (white) curve is the solution of the inversion of the Jeans equation adopting the\n              reference mass profile defined in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S8\">3.3</a>. The\n              hatched (gray) region indicates the 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence region around this\n              solution. For comparison, three <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) models are\n              shown (black curves). They correspond to the best-fit\n                <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) models of the MAMPOSSt analysis for a NFW\n                <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) model (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#S6\">3.1</a>), namely (from top to bottom at small radii) the C, T, and O\n              model. In both panels, the vertical dashed and dash-dotted (magenta) lines indicate\n              the location of <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,\n              respectively, and the horizontal dotted line indicates <i>&#946;</i>&#160;=&#160;0.\n                <i>Bottom panel</i>: passive and SF cluster members, separately. The red\n              solid (resp. blue dash-dotted) curve and orange (resp. cyan) hatched region represent\n              the solution of the inversion of the Jeans equation within the 1<i>&#963;</i>\n              confidence region for passive (resp. SF) cluster members.</p>\n          </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F15\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig16_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 16</span></a>\n            <p>Consistency of the shapes of the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq259.png\"></span>\n              profiles of the passive (solid red line) and SF (dashed blue line) cluster galaxy\n              populations. The profile for the SF galaxy population has been multiplied by 3.7 to\n              allow for a direct comparison with the profile of the passive galaxy population. The\n              hatched (orange) region indicates the 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence level of the\n              profile of the passive population (that for the SF population is not shown, but it is\n              much larger).</p>\n          </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F16\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F17.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig17_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F17.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 17</span></a>\n            <p>Pseudo phase-space density profiles\n                <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>)&#160;&#8801;&#160;<i>&#961;</i>/<i>&#963;</i><sup>3</sup>\n                (<i>left panels</i>) and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq262.png\"></span>\n                (<i>right panels</i>), as a function of clustercentric radius\n                <i>r</i>, within 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence regions (shaded area) for\n              all (<i>top panels</i>), passive (<i>middle panels</i>), and SF\n                (<i>bottom panels</i>) cluster members. The dashed lines are fixed-slope\n              best-fit relations\n                <i>Q</i>(<i>r</i>)&#160;&#8733;&#160;<i>r</i><sup>-1.84</sup> and\n                <i>Q</i><sub><i>r</i></sub>(<i>r</i>)&#160;&#8733;&#160;<i>r</i><sup>-1.92</sup>\n              to the sample of all galaxies, where the slopes are those found by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R55\">Dehnen &amp; McLaughlin (2005)</a> using\n              numerically simulated halos.</p>\n          </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F17\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F18.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig18_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F18.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 18</span></a>\n              <p>Relations between <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) and the logarithmic\n                derivative of the total mass density profile,\n                <i>&#947;</i>(<i>r</i>), for all, passive, and SF member galaxies\n                  (<i>top</i>, <i>middle</i>, and <i>bottom panel</i>,\n                respectively), within 1<i>&#963;</i> confidence regions (shaded regions), and\n                the theoretical <i>&#947;</i>&#160;&#8722;&#160;<i>&#946;</i> relation of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#R87\">Hansen &amp; Moore (2006)</a> (dashed line). The\n                vertical lines indicate the location of <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> (dashed) and\n                  <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> (dash-dotted).</p>\n            </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F18\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F19.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-fig19_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/F19.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. A.1</span></a>\n                <p>Difference of the <i>&#946;</i>(<i>r</i>) determined using the\n                  Clean and P+G samples of members. The solid (white), dashed (red), and dash-dotted\n                  (cyan) curves are for all, passive, and SF galaxies, respectively.\n                    1<i>&#963;</i> intervals on the differences are shown as shaded regions,\n                  with 45, 0, and 90 degrees orientation of the (gray, orange, blue) shading for\n                  all, passive, and SF galaxies, respectively. </p>\n              </td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html#F19\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</div>\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201321955\" data-edps_ref=\"aa21955-13\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. Zheng\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Department of Physics and Astronomy, The Johns Hopkins University, 3400 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21218, USA\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"CLASH-VLT: The mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of the z = 0.44 galaxy cluster MACS J1206.2-0847\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2013/09/26\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2013/10/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"558\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A1\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201321955\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2013A%26A...558A...1B\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2013/10/aa21955-13.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: individual: MACS J1206-0847\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: kinematics and dynamics\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: evolution\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"dark matter\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims. &lt;i/&gt;We constrain the mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of the &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a00.44 CLASH cluster MACS J1206.2-0847, using the projected phase-space distribution of cluster galaxies in combination with gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Methods. &lt;i/&gt;We use an unprecedented data-set of \u2243600 redshifts for cluster members, obtained as part of a VLT/VIMOS large program, to constrain the cluster mass profile over the radial range ~0\u20135 Mpc (0\u20132.5 virial radii) using the MAMPOSSt and Caustic methods. We then add external constraints from our previous gravitational lensing analysis. We invert the Jeans equation to obtain the velocity-anisotropy profiles of cluster members. With the mass-density and velocity-anisotropy profiles we then obtain the first determination of a cluster pseudo-phase-space density profile.&lt;i&gt;Results. &lt;i/&gt;The kinematics and lensing determinations of the cluster mass profile are in excellent agreement. This is very well fitted by a NFW model with mass &lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a0(1.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010&lt;sup&gt;15&lt;sup/&gt;\u00a0&lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt; and concentration &lt;i&gt;c&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01, only slightly higher than theoretical expectations. Other mass profile models also provide acceptable fits to our data, of (slightly) lower (Burkert, Hernquist, and Softened Isothermal Sphere) or comparable (Einasto) quality than NFW. The velocity anisotropy profiles of the passive and star-forming cluster members are similar, close to isotropic near the center and increasingly radial outside. Passive cluster members follow extremely well the theoretical expectations for the pseudo-phase-space density profile and the relation between the slope of the mass-density profile and the velocity anisotropy. Star-forming cluster members show marginal deviations from theoretical expectations.&lt;i&gt;Conclusions. &lt;i/&gt;This is the most accurate determination of a cluster mass profile out to a radius of 5 Mpc, and the only determination of the velocity-anisotropy and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of both passive and star-forming galaxies for an individual cluster. These profiles provide constraints on the dynamical history of the cluster and its galaxies. Prospects for extending this analysis to a larger cluster sample are discussed.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=M. H. Abdullah;citation_author=G. B. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div standalone=\"yes\"?>\n<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\" \"\">\n\n    <div id=\"annex\"><h2 class=\"sec\">Table 1 </h2>\n              <p>Values of the line-of-sight velocity dispersions, <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>,\n                and of the best-fit parameters of the galaxy number density profiles,\n                  <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>).</p>\n            <div class=\"tab\"><table width=\"100%\" class=\"fm\" frame=\"hsides\" rules=\"groups\">\n              <tr>\n                <td align=\"left\"> Sample</td>\n                <td align=\"center\">\n                  <i>&#963;</i>\n                  <sub>los</sub>\n                </td>\n                <td align=\"center\" colspan=\"3\"><i>n</i>(<i>R</i>)</td>\n              </tr>\n              <tr>\n     <td align=\"left\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\">spec</td>\n                <td align=\"center\">spec+phot</td>\n                <td          <td align=\"left\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td              <tr>\n                <td align=\"left\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n            </table></div><div class=\"history\">\n              <p><b>Notes.</b>The scale radius best-fit values are given for two selections of\n                members; &#8220;spec&#8221; refers to the purely spectroscopic selection (also used for the\n                determination of <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub>), &#8220;spec+phot&#8221; to the combined\n                spectroscopic and photometric selection (for details see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13.html#S4\">2.2</a>). The models used for <i>n</i>(<i>R</i>)\n                are the projected NFW (&#8220;pNFW&#8221;), and <a name=\"InR107\" id=\"InR107\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13.html#R107\">King\n                  (1962)</a>&#8217;s (&#8220;King&#8221;).</p>\n            </div></div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201321955\" data-edps_ref=\"aa21955-13\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico ico-info\"></span>\n\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t<p>Initial download of the metrics may take a while.</p>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n<script type=\"text/javascript\" Zheng\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Department of Physics and Astronomy, The Johns Hopkins University, 3400 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21218, USA\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"CLASH-VLT: The mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of the z = 0.44 galaxy cluster MACS J1206.2-0847\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2013/09/26\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2013/10/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"558\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A1\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201321955\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2013A%26A...558A...1B\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2013/10/aa21955-13.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: individual: MACS J1206-0847\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: kinematics and dynamics\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: evolution\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"dark matter\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims. &lt;i/&gt;We constrain the mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of the &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a00.44 CLASH cluster MACS J1206.2-0847, using the projected phase-space distribution of cluster galaxies in combination with gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Methods. &lt;i/&gt;We use an unprecedented data-set of \u2243600 redshifts for cluster members, obtained as part of a VLT/VIMOS large program, to constrain the cluster mass profile over the radial range ~0\u20135 Mpc (0\u20132.5 virial radii) using the MAMPOSSt and Caustic methods. We then add external constraints from our previous gravitational lensing analysis. We invert the Jeans equation to obtain the velocity-anisotropy profiles of cluster members. With the mass-density and velocity-anisotropy profiles we then obtain the first determination of a cluster pseudo-phase-space density profile.&lt;i&gt;Results. &lt;i/&gt;The kinematics and lensing determinations of the cluster mass profile are in excellent agreement. This is very well fitted by a NFW model with mass &lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a0(1.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010&lt;sup&gt;15&lt;sup/&gt;\u00a0&lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt; and concentration &lt;i&gt;c&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01, only slightly higher than theoretical expectations. Other mass profile models also provide acceptable fits to our data, of (slightly) lower (Burkert, Hernquist, and Softened Isothermal Sphere) or comparable (Einasto) quality than NFW. The velocity anisotropy profiles of the passive and star-forming cluster members are similar, close to isotropic near the center and increasingly radial outside. Passive cluster members follow extremely well the theoretical expectations for the pseudo-phase-space density profile and the relation between the slope of the mass-density profile and the velocity anisotropy. Star-forming cluster members show marginal deviations from theoretical expectations.&lt;i&gt;Conclusions. &lt;i/&gt;This is the most accurate determination of a cluster mass profile out to a radius of 5 Mpc, and the only determination of the velocity-anisotropy and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of both passive and star-forming galaxies for an individual cluster. These profiles provide constraints on the dynamical history of the cluster and its galaxies. Prospects for extending this analysis to a larger cluster sample are discussed.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=M. H. Abdullah;citation_author=G. B. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div               <td align=\"center\">\n                  <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq179.png\" /></span>\n                </td>\n                <td align=\"center\">\n                  <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq180.png\" /></span>\n                </td>\n align=\"center\">0.44</td>\n                <td align=\"center\">\n                  <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq182.png\" /></span>\n        </td>\n                <td align=\"center\">\n                  <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq181.png\" /></span>\n                </td>\n                <td align=\"center\">0.37 </td>\n              </tr>\n            </table></div><div class=\"history\">\n              <p><b>Notes.</b>Results of the MAMPOSSt analysis are shown as obtained using two\n                different input values of the best-fit\n                  <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub> parameter, determined outside\n                MAMPOSSt (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13.html#S4\">2.2</a> and Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/T2.html#T1\">1</a>). 1<i>&#963;</i> marginalized errors are\n                listed for all free parameters in the MAMPOSSt analysis. The scale radius\n                  <i>r</i><sub><i>&#961;</i></sub> is <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>\n                for the NFW and Einasto models,\n                  <i>r</i><sub>H</sub>,<i>r</i><sub>B</sub>,\n                and <i>r</i><sub>I</sub>, for the Hernquist, Burkert, and SIS\n                  <i>M</i>(<i>r</i>) models, respectively. The velocity\n                anisotropy (&#8220;Vel. anis.&#8221;) is <i>&#946;</i><sub>C</sub> for the C model and\n                  <i>&#946;</i><sub>&#8734;</sub> for the T and O models. The likelihood (&#8220;Lik.&#8221;)\n                ratios are given relative to the maximum among the models.</p>\n            </div></div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201321955\" data-edps_ref=\"aa21955-13\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico kinematics and dynamics\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: evolution\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"dark matter\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims. &lt;i/&gt;We constrain the mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of the &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a00.44 CLASH cluster MACS J1206.2-0847, using the projected phase-space distribution of cluster galaxies in combination with gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Methods. &lt;i/&gt;We use an unprecedented data-set of \u2243600 redshifts for cluster members, obtained as part of a VLT/VIMOS large program, to constrain the cluster mass profile over the radial range ~0\u20135 Mpc (0\u20132.5 virial radii) using the MAMPOSSt and Caustic methods. We then add external constraints from our previous gravitational lensing analysis. We invert the Jeans equation to obtain the velocity-anisotropy profiles of cluster members. With the mass-density and velocity-anisotropy profiles we then obtain the first determination of a cluster pseudo-phase-space density profile.&lt;i&gt;Results. &lt;i/&gt;The kinematics and lensing determinations of the cluster mass profile are in excellent agreement. This is very well fitted by a NFW model with mass &lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a0(1.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010&lt;sup&gt;15&lt;sup/&gt;\u00a0&lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt; and concentration &lt;i&gt;c&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01, only slightly higher than theoretical expectations. Other mass profile models also provide acceptable fits to our data, of (slightly) lower (Burkert, Hernquist, and Softened Isothermal Sphere) or comparable (Einasto) quality than NFW. The velocity anisotropy profiles of the passive and star-forming cluster members are similar, close to isotropic near the center and increasingly radial outside. Passive cluster members follow extremely well the theoretical expectations for the pseudo-phase-space density profile and the relation between the slope of the mass-density profile and the velocity anisotropy. Star-forming cluster members show marginal deviations from theoretical expectations.&lt;i&gt;Conclusions. &lt;i/&gt;This is the most accurate determination of a cluster mass profile out to a radius of 5 Mpc, and the only determination of the velocity-anisotropy and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of both passive and star-forming galaxies for an individual cluster. These profiles provide constraints on the dynamical history of the cluster and its galaxies. Prospects for extending this analysis to a larger cluster sample are discussed.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=M. H. Abdullah;citation_author=G. B. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div <div>\r\n    \n<div class=\"special_article green\">Free Access</div>\n    \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"article\">\r\n    <?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"ASCII\" member selection method (Clean vs. P+G).</p>\n              <div class=\"tab\"><table width=\"100%\" class=\"fm\" frame=\"hsides\" rules=\"groups\">\n                <tr>\n                  <td        <td align=\"left\"> MAMPOSSt</td>\n                  <td align=\"left\"> 0.05&#160;&#8804;&#160;<i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;1.96 Mpc</td>\n                  <td               </tr>\n                <tr>\n                  <td align=\"left\"></td>\n                  <td align=\"left\"></td>\n                  <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                </tr>\n                <tr>\n                  <td align=\"left\"> &#8211;</td>\n                  <td align=\"left\"><i>R</i>&#160;&#8804;&#160;1.96 Mpc</td>\n                  <td </td>\n                </tr>\n              </table></div><div class=\"history\">\n                <p><b>Notes.</b>We list the values of the ratios of several quantities,\n                    <i>r</i><sub>200</sub>,<i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>,<i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>,\n                  obtained using the samples of cluster members identified by the Clean and P+G\n                  method, respectively. We also list 1<i>&#963;</i> errors on these ratios.</p>\n              </div></div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201321955\" data-edps_ref=\"aa21955-13\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico Elbaz <br />\r\n</p>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"c13\">\r\n<p>ISSN: 0004-6361 ; e-ISSN: 1432-0746<br />\r\nFrequency: 12 volumes per year<br />\r\nPublished by: EDP Sciences<br Zheng\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Department of Physics and Astronomy, The Johns Hopkins University, 3400 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21218, USA\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"CLASH-VLT: The mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of the z = 0.44 galaxy cluster MACS J1206.2-0847\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2013/09/26\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2013/10/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"558\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A1\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201321955\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2013A%26A...558A...1B\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2013/10/aa21955-13.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: individual: MACS J1206-0847\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: kinematics and dynamics\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: evolution\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"dark matter\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims. &lt;i/&gt;We constrain the mass, velocity-anisotropy, and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of the &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a00.44 CLASH cluster MACS J1206.2-0847, using the projected phase-space distribution of cluster galaxies in combination with gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Methods. &lt;i/&gt;We use an unprecedented data-set of \u2243600 redshifts for cluster members, obtained as part of a VLT/VIMOS large program, to constrain the cluster mass profile over the radial range ~0\u20135 Mpc (0\u20132.5 virial radii) using the MAMPOSSt and Caustic methods. We then add external constraints from our previous gravitational lensing analysis. We invert the Jeans equation to obtain the velocity-anisotropy profiles of cluster members. With the mass-density and velocity-anisotropy profiles we then obtain the first determination of a cluster pseudo-phase-space density profile.&lt;i&gt;Results. &lt;i/&gt;The kinematics and lensing determinations of the cluster mass profile are in excellent agreement. This is very well fitted by a NFW model with mass &lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a0(1.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010&lt;sup&gt;15&lt;sup/&gt;\u00a0&lt;i&gt;M&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt; and concentration &lt;i&gt;c&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;200&lt;sub/&gt;\u00a0=\u00a06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01, only slightly higher than theoretical expectations. Other mass profile models also provide acceptable fits to our data, of (slightly) lower (Burkert, Hernquist, and Softened Isothermal Sphere) or comparable (Einasto) quality than NFW. The velocity anisotropy profiles of the passive and star-forming cluster members are similar, close to isotropic near the center and increasingly radial outside. Passive cluster members follow extremely well the theoretical expectations for the pseudo-phase-space density profile and the relation between the slope of the mass-density profile and the velocity anisotropy. Star-forming cluster members show marginal deviations from theoretical expectations.&lt;i&gt;Conclusions. &lt;i/&gt;This is the most accurate determination of a cluster mass profile out to a radius of 5 Mpc, and the only determination of the velocity-anisotropy and pseudo-phase-space density profiles of both passive and star-forming galaxies for an individual cluster. These profiles provide constraints on the dynamical history of the cluster and its galaxies. Prospects for extending this analysis to a larger cluster sample are discussed.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=M. H. Abdullah;citation_author=G. B. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n standalone=\"yes\"?>\n<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\" \"\">\n\n    <div id=\"annex\"><h2 class=\"sec\">Table 3 </h2>\n              <p>Best-fit dynamical parameters         <tr>\n                <td align=\"left\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n              </tr>\n              <tr>\n                <td align=\"left\"> MAMPOSSt+Caustic</td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td       <td align=\"left\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n              </tr>\n              <tr>\n                <td align=\"left\"> Lensing</td>\n                <td align=\"center\">\n                  <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13.html#R203\">U12</a>\n                </td>\n                <td align=\"center\"></td>\n                <td align=\"center\">1.96&#160;&#177;&#160;0.11 </td>\n                <td align=\"center\">0.34&#160;&#177;&#160;0.06 </td>\n                <td align=\"center\">1.37&#160;&#177;&#160;0.23 </td>\n                <td align=\"center\">5.8&#160;&#177;&#160;1.1 </td>\n              </tr>\n            </table></div><div class=\"history\">\n              <p><b>Notes.</b><i>N</i><sub>members</sub> is the number of cluster\n                members in the different samples used for the dynamical analyses. The results of the\n                  <i>&#963;</i><sub>los</sub> + <i>r</i><sub><i>&#957;</i></sub>\n                method are listed in italic to indicate that they are based on the simplified\n                assumptions that light traces mass and that the galaxy and DM particle velocity\n                distributions are identical. These assumption are dropped for the MAMPOSSt and\n                Caustic methods. The error on <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and that on\n                  <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub> are obtained by marginalizing on the other\n                parameters. The errors on <i>M</i><sub>200</sub> and\n                  <i>c</i><sub>200</sub> are derived from propagating the symmetrized\n                errors on <i>r</i><sub>200</sub> and <i>r</i><sub>-2</sub>. The\n                line labeled &#8220;MAMPOSSt+Caustic&#8221; lists the results obtained by the combination of the\n                MAMPOSSt and Caustic solutions. These results are therefore based on the samples\n                used separately for the MAMPOSSt and Caustic methods. Since the two samples largely\n                overlap and the two methods are not entirely independent, the errors are in this\n                case multiplied by <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2013/10/aa21955-13/aa21955-13-eq223.png\" /></span>.</p>\n            </div></div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201321955\" data-edps_ref=\"aa21955-13\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico
